description: A presentation on managing Millennials with host Peter VanRysdam and Javier Montes.
descriptionMD: A presentation on managing Millennials with host Peter VanRysdam and Javier Montes.
name: Millennials
subtitle: Millennials

episodes.title: Participation Was Enough
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.402
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.402 --> 00:00:05.980
Hello, and welcome to the show.

3
00:00:05.980 --> 00:00:08.960
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam,
and today we're talking about

4
00:00:08.960 --> 00:00:12.120
understanding millennials and
working with them in the workplace.

5
00:00:12.120 --> 00:00:14.160
And here to help us,
we have the author of the new book,

6
00:00:14.160 --> 00:00:16.270
Millennial Workforce Javier Montes
with us.

7
00:00:16.270 --> 00:00:17.350
Javier how are you doing?

8
00:00:17.350 --> 00:00:18.640
>> I'm doing fantastic, Peter.

9
00:00:18.640 --> 00:00:20.060
Very excited to be here.

10
00:00:20.060 --> 00:00:23.310
Very excited to talk about,
some of the content in my book.

11
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:28.140
So today we're gonna talk a lot about
understanding the millennial mindset and

12
00:00:28.140 --> 00:00:33.800
trying to understand, what is it that
shaped millennial in the workforce today?

13
00:00:33.800 --> 00:00:37.510
Like, their certain like experiences that
they went through as they were growing up,

14
00:00:37.510 --> 00:00:40.180
as they were going through their younger
years, their adolescent year that really

15
00:00:40.180 --> 00:00:45.270
shaped the way that this generation really
thinks and acts and makes decisions.

16
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:48.280
>> Fantastic, so for this episode,
where are we starting?

17
00:00:48.280 --> 00:00:51.310
>> So
let's start on participation was enough.

18
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:54.750
So this is a topic
that's very relevant and

19
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:58.320
I know some of us have heard about this
and this concept, and some of us have

20
00:00:58.320 --> 00:01:02.280
talked a little bit about it with some
of our peers but let's jump right into

21
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:06.410
why this was important and why millennials
think that participation is enough.

22
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:11.260
So as adolescents and as teenagers and
as kids millenials were growing up in

23
00:01:11.260 --> 00:01:16.790
a time where their parents were watching
the media and the parents were watching

24
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:20.410
the news and everywhere they looked there
was this concept coming up all over

25
00:01:20.410 --> 00:01:25.100
the place of protecting
a child's self-esteem.

26
00:01:25.100 --> 00:01:28.170
And a child's self-esteem was the most
important thing to these parents.

27
00:01:28.170 --> 00:01:30.290
Because the media kept telling and
pushing down our throats,

28
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:33.900
that a child's self-esteem,
if it was hurt at a young age,

29
00:01:33.900 --> 00:01:38.600
then it led to higher chances of suicide
when the children became adults.

30
00:01:38.600 --> 00:01:42.590
And this concept really drove home
through millennials' parents.

31
00:01:42.590 --> 00:01:45.180
So parents became a little freaked
out about this and they're like well,

32
00:01:45.180 --> 00:01:48.130
I don't want that to happen to my child, I
mean no parent wants to think about that.

33
00:01:49.250 --> 00:01:51.340
When the media was pushing this
down the parent's throats,

34
00:01:51.340 --> 00:01:55.260
what would happen is self esteem
became a very important concept and

35
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:57.560
protecting a child's self
esteem was very important.

36
00:01:57.560 --> 00:02:02.326
So going forward what would happen is the
parents of the millennials would go right

37
00:02:02.326 --> 00:02:04.882
into the millennials' personal lives, so

38
00:02:04.882 --> 00:02:08.335
in school, in their offside
activities like sport teams,

39
00:02:08.335 --> 00:02:13.447
if they joined any particular like extra
curricular activity, if they're in ballet,

40
00:02:13.447 --> 00:02:17.935
if they did any of those activities
parents were very much watching over their

41
00:02:17.935 --> 00:02:22.700
kids to make sure their self-esteem was
not being tarnished, to making sure that

42
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:27.518
they were protecting that nobody really
imposed on this child's self-esteem.

43
00:02:27.518 --> 00:02:31.128
Now what happened was that that put
a lot of pressure on the teachers,

44
00:02:31.128 --> 00:02:34.500
that put a lot of pressure on
coaches of teams, on instructors.

45
00:02:34.500 --> 00:02:39.365
And so much pressure came from
the parents to the coaches that this

46
00:02:39.365 --> 00:02:44.229
led to the coaches having to
recognize all the children equally so

47
00:02:44.229 --> 00:02:50.066
that one child didn't feel left out or
one child didn't feel less important,

48
00:02:50.066 --> 00:02:54.850
less valuable, or
less talented than the other children.

49
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:59.260
>> Yeah I know I played popcorn or
football growing up and I remember you had

50
00:02:59.260 --> 00:03:03.470
the rule where each player had to get
in for a certain number of plays.

51
00:03:03.470 --> 00:03:07.200
And it kind of felt odd almost those
players that only got in for two or

52
00:03:07.200 --> 00:03:07.790
three plays.

53
00:03:07.790 --> 00:03:11.090
You said well they're only putting them
in because they have to not because they

54
00:03:11.090 --> 00:03:11.930
earned that spot.

55
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:14.560
Kinda causes some conflict on the team.

56
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:19.390
So that kinda has some adverse
consequences for the kids.

57
00:03:19.390 --> 00:03:19.960
>> Yeah, so

58
00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:23.860
in theory this concept with the parents,
it sounded like it made sense.

59
00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:25.990
And it said, well,
we wanna protect our children and

60
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:27.990
we wanna make sure that
they're treated fairly.

61
00:03:27.990 --> 00:03:31.870
But the downside of that, which we
didn't really see it at the time, but

62
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:35.890
we're starting to see it today as these
millennials now come into the workforce,

63
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:37.900
as now they're put into real life.

64
00:03:37.900 --> 00:03:40.730
What happened was that these
parents deprived their children

65
00:03:40.730 --> 00:03:42.870
of a very important life lesson.

66
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:49.140
These parents took away this opportunity
for children to learn that in life,

67
00:03:49.140 --> 00:03:52.820
if you want to win,
you need to outwork the loser.

68
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:55.660
You need to put in more effort
if you want to be the best.

69
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:59.500
If you wanna be recognized, you need
to work harder than your counterparts.

70
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:02.776
And unfortunately the millennials
never learned that lesson.

71
00:04:02.776 --> 00:04:06.900
Millennials were taught, well if I show
up, I'm gonna get an opportunity to play

72
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:11.870
like you just mentioned and at the end of
the season everybody's gonna get a trophy.

73
00:04:11.870 --> 00:04:15.050
Coaches were put in a very difficult
position where coaches had to see

74
00:04:15.050 --> 00:04:17.640
how can I recognize each child?

75
00:04:17.640 --> 00:04:19.570
What am I gonna recognize this child for?

76
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:24.530
And that's were you got most improved
player, we got best effort, right?

77
00:04:24.530 --> 00:04:26.410
It wasn't just the MVP that got a trophy.

78
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:29.170
It wasn't just the person
who outperformed.

79
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:31.850
And the first thing that happened was
we taught these millennials that,

80
00:04:31.850 --> 00:04:35.400
you just show up and you're gonna get
recognized just like everybody else.

81
00:04:35.400 --> 00:04:37.280
The second thing that happened,

82
00:04:37.280 --> 00:04:41.120
was that we were teaching
the hard working students.

83
00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:45.550
We were teaching the actual students and
kids that were outperforming.

84
00:04:45.550 --> 00:04:49.790
We were teaching them that that
wasn't necessarily very valuable,

85
00:04:49.790 --> 00:04:53.110
because even though you worked hard and
you put in more effort, guess what?

86
00:04:53.110 --> 00:04:56.220
Everybody else will also get
recognized just like you.

87
00:04:56.220 --> 00:04:57.870
Maybe you might get a bigger trophy, but

88
00:04:57.870 --> 00:05:01.460
most of the time,
everybody have the same size trophy.

89
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:02.900
One would still say MVP.

90
00:05:02.900 --> 00:05:06.330
But the guy that got most improved,
it was the same exact trophy.

91
00:05:06.330 --> 00:05:10.450
Because the parents were putting so
much pressure on these coaches, right?

92
00:05:10.450 --> 00:05:12.460
And you could just imagine
the coach's position and

93
00:05:12.460 --> 00:05:13.645
the teacher's position, right?

94
00:05:13.645 --> 00:05:19.395
They were put in a very ugly and
nasty place we're they could

95
00:05:19.395 --> 00:05:23.885
not recognize a stellar performer because
the pressure came from the parents.

96
00:05:23.885 --> 00:05:26.555
Don't hurt my child's self
esteem even though he hasn't

97
00:05:26.555 --> 00:05:28.585
put in the extra effort to be the best.

98
00:05:28.585 --> 00:05:33.300
>> Sure so, what impact does that have
on those kids that grew up and now today

99
00:05:33.300 --> 00:05:37.280
are in the workforce, are they coming
to work with those same expectations?

100
00:05:37.280 --> 00:05:41.660
Is that something that as an employer or

101
00:05:41.660 --> 00:05:46.715
as a co-worker you want to help try to
break that or work with them on that.

102
00:05:46.715 --> 00:05:48.085
Where do we do from there?

103
00:05:48.085 --> 00:05:51.575
>> Yeah, so what's happening is,
as employers, first thing we need to

104
00:05:51.575 --> 00:05:56.285
understand is that when we start
labeling millennials as entitled.

105
00:05:56.285 --> 00:05:57.762
Right, this word Word
is tossed around a lot.

106
00:05:57.762 --> 00:06:00.062
A millennial shows up to work and
all of a sudden they're entitled.

107
00:06:00.062 --> 00:06:03.422
They think they're deserving of
promotions, of higher salaries, or

108
00:06:03.422 --> 00:06:06.892
they're deserving of corner offices.

109
00:06:06.892 --> 00:06:10.782
And we have to understand, to a certain
extent, this is no fault of their own.

110
00:06:10.782 --> 00:06:12.932
This is just the hand they were dealt.

111
00:06:12.932 --> 00:06:14.612
This is the world they were brought up in.

112
00:06:14.612 --> 00:06:18.630
This is the world that their
parents actually were the ones that

113
00:06:18.630 --> 00:06:20.020
raised them in this manner.

114
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:21.920
Because that's what was
going on at the time.

115
00:06:21.920 --> 00:06:24.310
So, as employers, the first thing we
need to do is start to recognize and

116
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:25.790
be a little more patient.

117
00:06:25.790 --> 00:06:27.880
We've got to understand and
explain to them and

118
00:06:27.880 --> 00:06:32.260
create the culture in our
organizations that they can fit into.

119
00:06:32.260 --> 00:06:35.960
That will actually help them understand
that if you want to be recognized,

120
00:06:35.960 --> 00:06:38.770
you need to outwork your counterparts,
right?

121
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:41.870
So what do we do as employers
to really create that culture?

122
00:06:41.870 --> 00:06:45.370
Number one that I always recommend to
all of the entrepreneurs I talk to and

123
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:47.800
all the managers and CEOs of companies,

124
00:06:47.800 --> 00:06:51.470
is create a very clear
scoreboard in your company.

125
00:06:51.470 --> 00:06:55.380
So teach your team very
clearly what it is to win.

126
00:06:55.380 --> 00:06:56.830
Right, define winning.

127
00:06:56.830 --> 00:07:00.610
Don't just say, okay well great, we had
a great year this year and sales were up.

128
00:07:00.610 --> 00:07:03.150
But that's not really relevant,
we need to be very specific.

129
00:07:03.150 --> 00:07:06.830
And we want to get a scoreboard for
every single position in the company,

130
00:07:06.830 --> 00:07:11.100
every single department, and find a way to
measure what the production looks like.

131
00:07:11.100 --> 00:07:13.190
Find a way to measure
what winning looks like.

132
00:07:13.190 --> 00:07:15.230
Sometimes it could be
customer service scores.

133
00:07:15.230 --> 00:07:18.390
Sometimes it could be number
of leaves that came in.

134
00:07:18.390 --> 00:07:21.550
Sometimes it could be maybe
our marketing department is

135
00:07:21.550 --> 00:07:23.460
measuring the social media traffic.

136
00:07:23.460 --> 00:07:26.930
Maybe it could be number of episodes
recorded, I mean there could be

137
00:07:26.930 --> 00:07:30.300
a number of things that really
affect what that person is doing and

138
00:07:30.300 --> 00:07:34.040
if you have a very clear scoreboard,
when a millennial comes on board,

139
00:07:34.040 --> 00:07:38.080
the millennial will learn and say okay, I
want to be at the top of that scoreboard.

140
00:07:38.080 --> 00:07:40.620
And when my name is constantly
showing up at the bottom or

141
00:07:40.620 --> 00:07:42.570
at the middle of the scoreboard,
I understand and

142
00:07:42.570 --> 00:07:46.430
I know what activities I need to
engage in to therefore become better.

143
00:07:46.430 --> 00:07:50.890
>> And that sounds like maybe giving
some clear expectations of not just hey,

144
00:07:50.890 --> 00:07:53.420
we want you here on the top, but
when you are on the bottom here

145
00:07:53.420 --> 00:07:56.440
are some things you can do
to work your way back up so

146
00:07:56.440 --> 00:08:00.780
we know what's expected of you and
help them achieve those goals.

147
00:08:00.780 --> 00:08:01.580
>> Exactly, exactly.

148
00:08:01.580 --> 00:08:07.040
I mean that couldn't be exactly
better said because most of the time,

149
00:08:07.040 --> 00:08:09.200
the organizations that I work with,
the companies that I talk to,

150
00:08:09.200 --> 00:08:10.380
the entrepreneurs,

151
00:08:10.380 --> 00:08:14.180
we have a definition in our mind of
what success looks like for our company.

152
00:08:14.180 --> 00:08:17.380
We know,
we have a very clear vision in our head

153
00:08:17.380 --> 00:08:20.120
of what we want
the organization to accomplish.

154
00:08:20.120 --> 00:08:25.140
Where most entrepreneurs, managers and
organizational leaders fail

155
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:30.540
is clearly articulating that vision and
that definition of success to our team.

156
00:08:30.540 --> 00:08:35.210
If we don't pull that information out of
our head and give it out to our team,

157
00:08:35.210 --> 00:08:39.760
either through a painted picture of where
we're trying to go, scoreboards, KPIs,

158
00:08:39.760 --> 00:08:44.200
dashboards, these kind of tools need to
be put into your organization to clearly

159
00:08:44.200 --> 00:08:48.130
articulate to your team what success
looks like, what does winning look like?

160
00:08:48.130 --> 00:08:48.920
And typically,

161
00:08:48.920 --> 00:08:52.610
if a company's doing it, they typically
do it on a very global scale.

162
00:08:52.610 --> 00:08:56.480
It's very few companies, and this is only
the highest performing companies that I've

163
00:08:56.480 --> 00:09:01.570
seen that do this well are the ones
that break it down to a granular level,

164
00:09:01.570 --> 00:09:05.280
down to each different department and
each different role, right?

165
00:09:05.280 --> 00:09:06.720
And that's where we need
to get really clear.

166
00:09:06.720 --> 00:09:10.110
So create a dashboard for
every single role in your company, so

167
00:09:10.110 --> 00:09:15.410
that every role knows exactly what
the definition of success in that role is.

168
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:17.420
And as a millennial coming
into that type of culture,

169
00:09:17.420 --> 00:09:21.990
into that type of organization, they will
quickly assimilate because they understand

170
00:09:21.990 --> 00:09:25.020
this is how I am being measured,
this is how I'm being rewarded, and

171
00:09:25.020 --> 00:09:26.630
this is what success looks like.

172
00:09:26.630 --> 00:09:31.240
so when I walk into a company as
a millennial, there's no obscure sense of

173
00:09:31.240 --> 00:09:34.510
who's winning, who's losing, who's
putting in the effort, who's out working.

174
00:09:34.510 --> 00:09:38.890
And I know that participation
in this workplace is not enough.

175
00:09:38.890 --> 00:09:42.410
So if I just showed up to work, that
doesn't mean I'm guaranteed my paycheck.

176
00:09:42.410 --> 00:09:45.570
I need to earn my place to be here and
if I'm not putting in the work,

177
00:09:45.570 --> 00:09:48.920
I'm not putting in the effort, one of
my counterparts can outperform me, and

178
00:09:48.920 --> 00:09:52.460
I can either possibly lose my job or
I'm not gonna be entitled to the bonuses,

179
00:09:52.460 --> 00:09:53.790
rewards, or higher commissions.

180
00:09:53.790 --> 00:09:57.560
>> And that's a great point you just
brought up that maybe participation is

181
00:09:57.560 --> 00:10:01.370
enough to keep your job but if your
compensation is tied to that if it's

182
00:10:01.370 --> 00:10:05.080
a sales position and you're on commission
or there are those bonus programs.

183
00:10:05.080 --> 00:10:07.530
That's maybe how we kind of
get that message across that

184
00:10:07.530 --> 00:10:09.890
participation might have been
enough when you were a kid but

185
00:10:09.890 --> 00:10:11.680
it's not enough here in
the workforce today.

186
00:10:11.680 --> 00:10:14.560
But are there any other topics you'd
like to cover in this episode?

187
00:10:14.560 --> 00:10:16.090
>> No, that's pretty much the main gist.

188
00:10:16.090 --> 00:10:20.120
I just really want to be clear and
explain to the entrepreneurs and

189
00:10:20.120 --> 00:10:25.080
the leaders and the organizational leaders
that just labeling the millennials and

190
00:10:25.080 --> 00:10:26.330
telling them, you're entitled.

191
00:10:26.330 --> 00:10:29.580
And I'm not gonna hire a millennial,
or just letting them go.

192
00:10:29.580 --> 00:10:31.630
We need to turn around and
really start to look in the mirror.

193
00:10:31.630 --> 00:10:33.830
And say,
well what are we doing as an organization?

194
00:10:33.830 --> 00:10:38.180
What are we doing as a team to really
align everybody in our organization,

195
00:10:38.180 --> 00:10:41.490
and teach our millennials, and everybody
in the workforce, because right now we're

196
00:10:41.490 --> 00:10:44.830
talking specifically about millennials,
but there's not one single generational

197
00:10:44.830 --> 00:10:48.160
person on your team that will not
appreciate this kind of clarity.

198
00:10:48.160 --> 00:10:52.740
There's not one single person in your
company right now that will not get value

199
00:10:52.740 --> 00:10:57.200
and prove their performance if we can
be extremely clear about measurements.

200
00:10:57.200 --> 00:10:59.470
So let's not be so
quick to label them as entitled.

201
00:10:59.470 --> 00:11:02.280
But let's take a look in the mirror and
really think.

202
00:11:02.280 --> 00:11:05.470
What are we doing and
how are we adding to this in our culture?

203
00:11:05.470 --> 00:11:08.270
Are we creating a culture
by default that things just

204
00:11:08.270 --> 00:11:11.150
happen because I expect everybody
to know what success looks like?

205
00:11:11.150 --> 00:11:14.750
Or are we creating a purposeful
culture that creates and

206
00:11:14.750 --> 00:11:17.630
empowers our team to be leaders and
be winners.

207
00:11:17.630 --> 00:11:20.760
>> All right, great Javier,
that's a lot of fantastic information.

208
00:11:20.760 --> 00:11:23.760
It'll help us out, and
it'll get a lot more information on

209
00:11:23.760 --> 00:11:26.680
working with millennials and
understanding the nuances of that.

210
00:11:26.680 --> 00:11:29.280
We're gonna have to save that for
future episodes.

211
00:11:29.280 --> 00:11:32.170
So going ahead and signing off,
I've been your host Peter VanRysdam.

212
00:11:32.170 --> 00:11:33.958
>> And I'm Javier Montes,
the millennial expert.

213
00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:38.642
>> And we'll see

214
00:11:38.642 --> 00:11:43.720
you next time.

215
00:11:43.720 --> 00:11:45.185
[MUSIC]

understanding millennials.

Javier Montes,

into the new way of doing things.

217
00:10:41.250 --> 00:10:45.120
And again, Amazon's a great example
First there was six to eight weeks.

218
00:10:45.120 --> 00:10:47.290
Amazon said,
no I want people to get it in a week so

219
00:10:47.290 --> 00:10:50.060
we're gonna build our organization
a way to get it in a week.

220
00:10:50.060 --> 00:10:52.470
And all the sudden,
that became crazy, right?

221
00:10:52.470 --> 00:10:54.200
That was like, my god,
you know Amazon is doing this thing,

222
00:10:54.200 --> 00:10:55.110
you get delivery in a week.

223
00:10:55.110 --> 00:10:56.210
Wow, that's crazy, that's crazy.

224
00:10:56.210 --> 00:10:58.490
But they didn't stop there,
they didn't stop there,

225
00:10:58.490 --> 00:11:01.330
within a few years, their team come and
say, hey, guess what?

226
00:11:01.330 --> 00:11:05.380
We're gonna try this concept out,
we're gonna send you things in two days.

227
00:11:05.380 --> 00:11:06.170
My God!

228
00:11:06.170 --> 00:11:07.750
Amazon prime!
This is the craziest thing!

229
00:11:07.750 --> 00:11:08.440
Two days!

230
00:11:08.440 --> 00:11:10.890
Right?
How can any competitor compete with that?

231
00:11:10.890 --> 00:11:12.630
You can't.
It's impossible, right?

232
00:11:12.630 --> 00:11:14.140
You cannot even live with that.

233
00:11:14.140 --> 00:11:16.220
But you raise the standard
of your industry, and

234
00:11:16.220 --> 00:11:17.610
the world continues to progress.

235
00:11:17.610 --> 00:11:18.560
And then guess what?

236
00:11:18.560 --> 00:11:20.390
Amazon has not stopped there.

237
00:11:20.390 --> 00:11:21.730
Since then, they launched another product.

238
00:11:21.730 --> 00:11:23.490
Amazon Prime Now.

239
00:11:23.490 --> 00:11:25.060
Two hours, right?

240
00:11:25.060 --> 00:11:28.920
They have certain products that they sell,
there's only certain areas that offer

241
00:11:28.920 --> 00:11:32.490
Amazon Prime Now, but
in two hours you can get your products.

242
00:11:32.490 --> 00:11:34.235
Now, you've just opened
up a whole can of worms.

243
00:11:34.235 --> 00:11:36.610
[LAUGH] You say, it's impossible.

244
00:11:36.610 --> 00:11:38.730
So any of your competitors
will look at your company and

245
00:11:38.730 --> 00:11:40.970
say, There's no way we can
do something in two hours.

246
00:11:40.970 --> 00:11:41.560
That's impossible.

247
00:11:41.560 --> 00:11:42.490
What if our customers order this?

248
00:11:42.490 --> 00:11:43.860
What if our customers order that?

249
00:11:43.860 --> 00:11:48.300
But those constraints get erased
when you come in somebody as

250
00:11:48.300 --> 00:11:50.470
quote unquote label it naive.

251
00:11:50.470 --> 00:11:54.920
I would call it not tainted with
being in your industry so long.

252
00:11:54.920 --> 00:11:58.110
Their naiveness will challenge
you to get better and

253
00:11:58.110 --> 00:11:59.500
open up new ways of doing things.

254
00:11:59.500 --> 00:12:02.420
And as I mentioned,
Amazon Prime right now I mean,

255
00:12:02.420 --> 00:12:04.600
they're doing things in
drones in probably what?

256
00:12:04.600 --> 00:12:05.725
Half an hour.

257
00:12:05.725 --> 00:12:09.737
[CROSSTALK] I mean, that's crazy and
I guarantee you, mark my words,

258
00:12:09.737 --> 00:12:11.103
it will not stop there.

259
00:12:11.103 --> 00:12:14.870
You will literally start seeing
things instantly, instantly.

260
00:12:14.870 --> 00:12:16.800
That's where it's going and
Amazon is not gonna stop there.

261
00:12:16.800 --> 00:12:19.560
Perfect example of
a company that guarantees

262
00:12:19.560 --> 00:12:23.480
it has a strong team of millennials that
continues to challenge their mindset.

263
00:12:23.480 --> 00:12:27.590
And again, in this concept of instant
gratification We got to stop looking at

264
00:12:27.590 --> 00:12:30.870
it as a bad thing, and figure out
how can we leverage this talent.

265
00:12:30.870 --> 00:12:34.440
How can we leverage this into our
organizations, and really help us

266
00:12:34.440 --> 00:12:39.660
bring power, really dominate our
industry by the power of Millennials.

267
00:12:39.660 --> 00:12:43.780
>> And I think Mike you take away from
this episode is that instant gratification

268
00:12:43.780 --> 00:12:46.660
is not a bad thing, and say aw these
guys want instant gratification.

269
00:12:46.660 --> 00:12:50.570
But instead we say hey, this is something
we should strive for in our company,

270
00:12:50.570 --> 00:12:52.950
so that makes a lot of sense.

271
00:12:52.950 --> 00:12:54.410
Any final thoughts?

272
00:12:54.410 --> 00:12:56.210
>> No, I think that's pretty much it.

273
00:12:56.210 --> 00:12:57.540
That covers the concept and

274
00:12:57.540 --> 00:13:02.730
just understanding that their mindset
Comes from a place of their entire world,

275
00:13:02.730 --> 00:13:05.460
as they were growing up,
was all instantly gratified.

276
00:13:05.460 --> 00:13:06.740
They didn't know any different.

277
00:13:06.740 --> 00:13:09.790
They didn't know that they had to wait for
certain things.

278
00:13:09.790 --> 00:13:13.630
So again, the culture really dominates and
it's our job as entrepenuers and as

279
00:13:13.630 --> 00:13:18.930
business owners and as business leaders to
really create a culture where we embrace

280
00:13:18.930 --> 00:13:22.810
this kind of thinking, and not necessarily
just reject and flat out say This is not

281
00:13:22.810 --> 00:13:28.180
what I want here, cuz again that will lead
to your company possibly being extinct.

282
00:13:28.180 --> 00:13:30.060
>> Fantastic.
Well that's a very important concept.

283
00:13:30.060 --> 00:13:33.860
I know we've got a lot more great concepts
in the book and we're gonna cover a lot

284
00:13:33.860 --> 00:13:37.690
of those so definitely stick around and
stay tuned for more episodes.

285
00:13:37.690 --> 00:13:40.660
But signing off for this one,
I'm your host Peter Van Reisdam.

286
00:13:40.660 --> 00:13:42.540
>> And I'm Javier Montez,
a millennial expert.

287
00:13:42.540 --> 00:13:43.461
See you in the next episode.

288
00:13:43.461 --> 00:13:53.461
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Helicopter Parents
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.853
[SOUND] Hello and welcome to the show.

2
00:00:05.853 --> 00:00:09.496
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and today
we're continuing in our series talking

3
00:00:09.496 --> 00:00:11.930
about understanding
Millennials in the workforce.

4
00:00:11.930 --> 00:00:15.200
And here to help us with that we
have the author of the new book,

5
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:17.370
Millennial Workforce, Javier Montes.

6
00:00:17.370 --> 00:00:18.240
Javier, how you doing?

7
00:00:18.240 --> 00:00:19.820
>> I'm doing fantastic Peter.

8
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:21.390
I'm excited to be here, and

9
00:00:21.390 --> 00:00:25.030
really dive real deep into
understanding the Millennial mindset.

10
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:28.760
And actually what makes Millennials
think and act the way that they do.

11
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:30.930
>> Okay, so what are we talking
about in this episode then?

12
00:00:30.930 --> 00:00:34.950
>> In this episode we gonna dive into
a really cool concept that a lot of

13
00:00:34.950 --> 00:00:40.020
people haven't heard, some people have,
but it's a term called helicopter parent.

14
00:00:40.020 --> 00:00:41.315
Ever heard of that, Peter?

15
00:00:41.315 --> 00:00:41.815
>> I certainly have.
>> You have?

16
00:00:41.815 --> 00:00:42.315
>> I have.

17
00:00:42.315 --> 00:00:42.915
>> Good, good.

18
00:00:42.915 --> 00:00:44.881
So let's get right into it.

19
00:00:44.881 --> 00:00:45.693
Let's define it.

20
00:00:45.693 --> 00:00:46.994
What is a helicopter parent, and

21
00:00:46.994 --> 00:00:49.770
where did this come from?
I think the term was coined probably

22
00:00:49.770 --> 00:00:51.430
around the year 2000 or so.

23
00:00:51.430 --> 00:00:54.460
And this term came from two gentlemen.

24
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:55.110
I forgot their names.

25
00:00:55.110 --> 00:00:59.934
But they coined this term to
describe parents hovering over

26
00:00:59.934 --> 00:01:04.087
their children so
as to protect them from any harm.

27
00:01:04.087 --> 00:01:07.882
And that's why they are called helicopter
parents cuz they're hovering over their

28
00:01:07.882 --> 00:01:09.068
kinds like a helicopter.

29
00:01:09.068 --> 00:01:12.370
And this is a term that has
a negative connotation I would say.

30
00:01:12.370 --> 00:01:13.688
Is that something you'd agree with?

31
00:01:13.688 --> 00:01:16.100
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
its definitely a negative connotation.

32
00:01:16.100 --> 00:01:19.900
I think that, this is something
that happened during this time that

33
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:21.140
probably should not have happened.

34
00:01:21.140 --> 00:01:24.190
But again,
it shaped the way the Millennials grew up.

35
00:01:24.190 --> 00:01:25.620
And it shaped the way that they think.

36
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:27.190
And this is part of their life experience.

37
00:01:27.190 --> 00:01:29.870
So now what we can do
is we can know from it.

38
00:01:29.870 --> 00:01:35.781
We know that's probably not
the best way of parenting.

39
00:01:35.781 --> 00:01:37.230
Hindsight is always 20/20, right?

40
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:39.680
We learn from our past experiences.

41
00:01:39.680 --> 00:01:41.530
And at the time it may
have seemed to make sense.

42
00:01:41.530 --> 00:01:45.910
And again Millenial parents were
thinking this was the way to do it.

43
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:48.820
And we'll talk now about what happened.

44
00:01:48.820 --> 00:01:50.968
And what did that create?

45
00:01:50.968 --> 00:01:54.870
>> And I think, there's a lot of
arguments for why this has taken place.

46
00:01:54.870 --> 00:01:57.890
But I remember as a kid,
we'd hop on our bikes and

47
00:01:57.890 --> 00:01:59.840
we'd drive to the convenience store.

48
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:02.590
And we couldn't have been more than 7 or
8 years old.

49
00:02:02.590 --> 00:02:06.515
And we're a mile and a half down
the street, crossing a big road.

50
00:02:06.515 --> 00:02:08.456
And I've got an eight year old daughter,
and

51
00:02:08.456 --> 00:02:10.304
I can't imagine letting that happen now.

52
00:02:10.304 --> 00:02:11.893
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I think part of that,

53
00:02:11.893 --> 00:02:15.865
you kind of make the case in your mind of,
there's all these predators out there now.

54
00:02:15.865 --> 00:02:17.235
There's all these bad
things that can happen.

55
00:02:17.235 --> 00:02:19.995
But those things existed back then too.

56
00:02:19.995 --> 00:02:23.930
>> Yeah, they did exist back then.

57
00:02:23.930 --> 00:02:27.400
And I think that this, maybe,
has come to fruition a lot more.

58
00:02:27.400 --> 00:02:28.530
Maybe because of media.

59
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:32.730
Or maybe because it's just been pushed so
much and repeated so much.

60
00:02:32.730 --> 00:02:35.440
That I've found that people
repeat a lot of things and

61
00:02:35.440 --> 00:02:38.220
it tends to create more
fear than anything else.

62
00:02:38.220 --> 00:02:43.210
But nonetheless, we did learn that
helicopter parenting is not necessarily

63
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:44.830
the best way to parent children.

64
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:46.720
So let's talk about what
happened to these Millennials.

65
00:02:46.720 --> 00:02:47.666
What happened to these Millennials?

66
00:02:47.666 --> 00:02:49.570
And what did they experience?

67
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:51.640
And how did that affect their life?

68
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:53.730
And how does it affect them
now in their work place,

69
00:02:53.730 --> 00:02:57.840
by having parents that were
helicoptering over these children?

70
00:02:57.840 --> 00:02:59.640
So, let's define what happened.

71
00:02:59.640 --> 00:03:03.280
So children would be going to school,
children would be in sports teams,

72
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:05.300
we talked about this
in a previous episode.

73
00:03:05.300 --> 00:03:08.810
And the parents would literally
be protecting their child.

74
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:11.270
We talked in another episode about
protecting your self-esteem.

75
00:03:11.270 --> 00:03:12.060
But aside from that,

76
00:03:12.060 --> 00:03:17.110
they were protecting their child from any
harm that would come to this child, right?

77
00:03:17.110 --> 00:03:18.210
So what would happen?

78
00:03:18.210 --> 00:03:24.190
I think a couple of the main things that
were very prominent during this time where

79
00:03:24.190 --> 00:03:29.410
are the parents being involved with
the child's schooling and their teachers.

80
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:33.268
So when the child would get a bad
grade at school the parents

81
00:03:33.268 --> 00:03:37.207
became extremely involved,
went to the teacher and said,

82
00:03:37.207 --> 00:03:40.221
teacher why did you give
my child this grade?

83
00:03:40.221 --> 00:03:44.960
Now, it sounds kind of crazy now
that we're talking about it.

84
00:03:44.960 --> 00:03:50.200
But parents started to blame the teachers,
the educators,

85
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:55.450
the coaches, for giving the students
the grades that they earned.

86
00:03:55.450 --> 00:03:57.850
>> And even in cases, the other kid.

87
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:01.494
Well why did you push my kid in the soccer
game, you know to the other children?

88
00:04:01.494 --> 00:04:04.390
Or why aren't you playing my kid enough,
to the coach.

89
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:06.900
>> Yeah, that's exactly what had happened.

90
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:08.560
And what did this create?

91
00:04:08.560 --> 00:04:09.610
Okay, two things it created.

92
00:04:09.610 --> 00:04:13.440
The first thing that it created
was the Millennial child

93
00:04:13.440 --> 00:04:19.050
became dependant on always having
a bodyguard, per say, to defend them.

94
00:04:19.050 --> 00:04:23.820
So many millenials didn't necessarily
learn how to defend themselves,

95
00:04:23.820 --> 00:04:25.280
how to stand up for themselves.

96
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:28.770
And even if they did a little bit,
they always were used to having somebody

97
00:04:28.770 --> 00:04:31.600
behind them,
somebody that would stand up for them.

98
00:04:31.600 --> 00:04:32.283
And speak for

99
00:04:32.283 --> 00:04:36.453
them and kind of, this person that
would have my back 1,000% of the time.

100
00:04:36.453 --> 00:04:37.890
So that's the first thing that happened.

101
00:04:37.890 --> 00:04:39.220
They got used to that.

102
00:04:39.220 --> 00:04:42.210
And that was, again,
the world that was created for them.

103
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:46.680
The second thing that happened was
that this type of parenting created

104
00:04:46.680 --> 00:04:51.730
this mindset of the parents
wanting to be friends,

105
00:04:51.730 --> 00:04:54.850
'' best friends'', with their children.

106
00:04:54.850 --> 00:04:58.780
They no longer created this
authority relationship.

107
00:04:58.780 --> 00:05:02.150
Where I'm the parent and you're the child,
therefore, I am the authority.

108
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:05.440
They created this concept of,
we're friends.

109
00:05:05.440 --> 00:05:06.600
And we're best friends.

110
00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:09.170
And we're gonna stay best friends for
our entire lives.

111
00:05:09.170 --> 00:05:12.905
And again,
while that sounded great at the beginning.

112
00:05:12.905 --> 00:05:17.590
Let's fast forward today and
how did it affect these children?

113
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:21.110
So, how it really affected
these children is, number one,

114
00:05:21.110 --> 00:05:25.160
they became best friends
with their parents.

115
00:05:25.160 --> 00:05:30.110
And lost what it was like to
have a sense of authority.

116
00:05:30.110 --> 00:05:34.822
So when parents are no longer here,
when they go into the workplace,

117
00:05:34.822 --> 00:05:38.803
when they go into schooling,
when they go into the world,

118
00:05:38.803 --> 00:05:43.598
these Millennials have, I don't wanna say,
a full loss of respect,

119
00:05:43.598 --> 00:05:47.046
but a much lesser level of respect for
authority.

120
00:05:47.046 --> 00:05:47.561
Right, so

121
00:05:47.561 --> 00:05:51.320
you're gonna see that Millennials will
start to challenge authority a lot.

122
00:05:51.320 --> 00:05:55.340
They will, in essence,
talk back to authority figures.

123
00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:57.844
Because they don't see
them as much as authority.

124
00:05:57.844 --> 00:06:00.324
They were taught that these
are my best friends and

125
00:06:00.324 --> 00:06:03.112
you can challenge what they say and
verify it yourself.

126
00:06:03.112 --> 00:06:05.551
So just because an authority
figure says something,

127
00:06:05.551 --> 00:06:08.656
you don't accept it as necessarily true,
you go find it yourself.

128
00:06:08.656 --> 00:06:11.130
>> Do you see then, at the same time,

129
00:06:11.130 --> 00:06:17.580
do they expect that same level of watching
over and protecting you from their boss?

130
00:06:17.580 --> 00:06:20.460
>> Yes, so they are looking for
that as well.

131
00:06:20.460 --> 00:06:23.695
So in every relationship
with this authority figure,

132
00:06:23.695 --> 00:06:27.506
they also expect that their
boss has their back a 1,000%.

133
00:06:27.506 --> 00:06:29.290
Now that's not necessarily a bad thing.

134
00:06:29.290 --> 00:06:33.610
But we have to understand that
the relationship that they're expecting

135
00:06:33.610 --> 00:06:36.010
is very similar to that
kind of relationship.

136
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:39.410
So when they have a boss who
is not defending them or

137
00:06:39.410 --> 00:06:43.496
a boss who is not ''protecting'' them,
this creates a disconnect.

138
00:06:43.496 --> 00:06:46.590
And the Millennial can
possibly leave that company or

139
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:50.310
go find another company because they're
looking for that kind of relationship.

140
00:06:50.310 --> 00:06:53.152
But going back to the other topic,

141
00:06:53.152 --> 00:06:58.710
which was about the Millennials
challenging authority.

142
00:06:58.710 --> 00:07:00.000
It sounds like a bad thing, right?

143
00:07:00.000 --> 00:07:05.880
But again, I keep stressing this concept
of no generation is better or worse.

144
00:07:05.880 --> 00:07:07.240
There's differences and

145
00:07:07.240 --> 00:07:10.370
if we can understand those differences
then we can meet somewhere halfway.

146
00:07:10.370 --> 00:07:14.080
And really leverage the power of
each of the generations, right?

147
00:07:14.080 --> 00:07:18.630
So what does them challenging
authority have to do with business?

148
00:07:18.630 --> 00:07:20.610
And how can we use this in our companies?

149
00:07:20.610 --> 00:07:23.440
Well, again, we talked about
this in a previous episode, but

150
00:07:23.440 --> 00:07:28.000
a Millennial will challenge
something that you're saying.

151
00:07:28.000 --> 00:07:31.020
So when a boss says something,
when a supervisor says something,

152
00:07:31.020 --> 00:07:33.660
the Millennial will come back and
say well, why?

153
00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:34.472
And ask why.

154
00:07:34.472 --> 00:07:35.119
And probe why.

155
00:07:35.119 --> 00:07:37.658
And a lot of times,
us as entrepreneurs, again,

156
00:07:37.658 --> 00:07:41.730
we're going back to we just do things
because we've always done them that way.

157
00:07:41.730 --> 00:07:42.600
>> Because I said so.

158
00:07:42.600 --> 00:07:44.040
Because I'm the boss, right?

159
00:07:44.040 --> 00:07:45.052
>> Right, exactly.

160
00:07:45.052 --> 00:07:51.135
Millennials have a very low tolerance
to accept those kind of answers.

161
00:07:51.135 --> 00:07:54.235
Millennials will not sit down and
stay quiet when you give those types

162
00:07:54.235 --> 00:07:56.455
of answers,
because that's not a justified answer.

163
00:07:56.455 --> 00:08:00.535
And if we sit back and think about it,

If we're talking about business and

How can you push it down just because

The other answer we could typically

well we've always done it that way.

00:08:22.420 --> 00:08:25.980
And that's the way it needs to be

00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:30.260
Well, like I mentioned before, what worked

174
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:35.730
So if we can have an open mind to look and

00:10:49.255 --> 00:10:51.980
It can truly revolutionize
your organization.

00:10:51.980 --> 00:10:54.940
And truly revolutionize

216
00:10:54.940 --> 00:10:57.650
If you're open enough to
embrace that concept and

We can do this.

And most of the time with

00:11:43.930 --> 00:11:45.100
>> Yeah.

>> This is a great concept
because I don't think this

Millennials, on the other hand,

They're really, really big on this.

I don't know.

Everybody, let's do it!

00:06:37.770 --> 00:06:38.490
I love it.
And they get

00:06:40.280 --> 00:06:42.910
Now what kind of energy or chemistry

What kind of motivation does that

That is contagious.

Positive energy is very, very contagious.

00:06:50.305 --> 00:06:54.575

The team may become

But if you have millennials who

00:07:47.140 --> 00:07:47.790
We can do it.

00:07:47.790 --> 00:07:51.690

00:07:54.920 --> 00:07:57.480

00:08:01.710 --> 00:08:06.530

fun of sometimes, but on the flip side,

182
00:08:38.315 --> 00:08:42.645
>> Yeah, definitely, and that kind

00:08:42.645 --> 00:08:46.625
And we can argue and talk about all

00:08:46.625 --> 00:08:49.345
But the truth is that
when your team is happy,

00:08:49.345 --> 00:08:53.797
that will radiate 10,000%

00:08:53.797 --> 00:08:58.337

how amazing not only your product is, but

00:08:58.337 --> 00:08:59.447

00:08:59.447 --> 00:09:01.269
How excited your employees are.

00:09:01.269 --> 00:09:03.687
How excited your team members are.

00:09:03.687 --> 00:09:06.777
And that will permeate throughout
your entire organization,

00:09:06.777 --> 00:09:08.187

00:09:08.187 --> 00:09:11.847

00:09:11.847 --> 00:09:16.470
business with as an organization will

00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:18.050
And I'm sure we've all been through it,

00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:24.495

00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:29.700

Millennials, again, we can give words

People that I talk to,

00:09:49.630 --> 00:09:51.420

[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

00:09:55.910 --> 00:09:58.420

This generation is optimistic.

00:10:15.380 --> 00:10:16.070
And you know what?

That road block may not even exist.

00:10:17.950 --> 00:10:19.410
Yes, I agree we should prepare for it.

00:10:19.410 --> 00:10:22.210

00:10:41.260 --> 00:10:42.570

00:11:20.255 --> 00:11:23.760

00:12:33.460 --> 00:12:37.590

00:13:07.090 --> 00:13:09.300

>> I think it's pretty much head,

this is the time to really

This is the time to bring

I want them to be together.

48

00:02:21.976 --> 00:02:25.489
I want my personal life and

Now, what is that?

55

56
00:02:42.390 --> 00:02:45.040
I think that's one of those

57
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:45.950
All throughout their life,

58
00:02:45.950 --> 00:02:49.710
ever since they were small, group

59
00:02:49.710 --> 00:02:53.870

00:02:53.870 --> 00:02:56.320

And I think Millennials developed
a very strong relationship

00:03:07.400 --> 00:03:08.510

00:03:08.510 --> 00:03:11.414

00:03:14.829 --> 00:03:18.210

00:03:19.140 --> 00:03:21.810
And school be equivalent

But through these group projects,

So, they're in this world of

And all of a sudden,

00:03:40.475 --> 00:03:42.313

79
00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:52.040
All right, don't do the stuff that

Previous generations had a very

00:04:18.230 --> 00:04:20.680

So it's creating a little bit of a

So Millennials want to have this bond,

00:04:46.580 --> 00:04:49.970

00:04:49.970 --> 00:04:52.430
So there's been a little

And the Millennials are saying,

104
00:04:54.840 --> 00:04:56.960
So it really comes from the leadership,

And what I found in my company and

The best organizations that have the best

are creating opportunities for

Their personal and

>> So I think that Millennials

I don't see that,

00:08:01.290 --> 00:08:03.540

00:08:03.540 --> 00:08:08.450

00:08:08.450 --> 00:08:09.760

00:08:09.760 --> 00:08:11.300

00:08:11.300 --> 00:08:14.600

00:08:14.600 --> 00:08:16.930

00:08:16.930 --> 00:08:23.380

millenials are big on family.

okay I still get to keep my personal life.

There work life becomes

because it's one thing.

We need to encourage that our team

We need to set rooms

In my company one of

The sense of security is not in their

They care about being happy and
