WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.284
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.284 --> 00:00:05.560
Hello and welcome to the show.

3
00:00:05.560 --> 00:00:09.800
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and today
we're continuing in our series talking

4
00:00:09.800 --> 00:00:12.980
about what Millennials are looking for
in the workplace.

5
00:00:12.980 --> 00:00:15.770
And here to help us we have
the expert who wrote the book,

6
00:00:15.770 --> 00:00:17.820
Millennial Workforce, Javier Montes.

7
00:00:17.820 --> 00:00:18.810
Javier, how are you doing today?

8
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:21.150
>> I'm doing fantastic, Peter,
thank you for having me today.

9
00:00:21.150 --> 00:00:25.410
It's a pleasure to be here talking about
my favorite topic which is millennials in

10
00:00:25.410 --> 00:00:26.440
the work force.

11
00:00:26.440 --> 00:00:28.290
We're gonna cover today
some amazing stuff.

12
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:29.760
I hope you guys are ready.

13
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:31.790
Grab your pen and paper, take some notes.

14
00:00:31.790 --> 00:00:33.160
We're gonna dive right into it.

15
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:34.463
So what we're talking about today, Peter?

16
00:00:34.463 --> 00:00:38.240
Well, looks like we're talking about
providing mentorship and training which

17
00:00:38.240 --> 00:00:41.915
we've kinda talked about, acknowledging
strengths and things in the past.

18
00:00:41.915 --> 00:00:45.940
And now we're moving on to maybe helping
them build upon those strengths.

19
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:47.860
So where do we go in this one?

20
00:00:47.860 --> 00:00:52.170
>> So this is one of those topics which is
what millennials want in the workplace.

21
00:00:52.170 --> 00:00:56.400
This is one of those subheadings that
you can incorporate into your business

22
00:00:56.400 --> 00:00:59.640
right away that will help
you increase retention and

23
00:00:59.640 --> 00:01:01.550
also attract new millenials
into your company.

24
00:01:01.550 --> 00:01:05.090
Because this is one of those things
that millenials are looking for

25
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:07.860
when they are deciding on
a company to work for.

26
00:01:07.860 --> 00:01:11.320
They want you to provide mentorship and
training.

27
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:12.960
This is key.
And mentorship and training,

28
00:01:12.960 --> 00:01:15.130
they seem similar but
they're two different things, and

29
00:01:15.130 --> 00:01:15.940
we're gonna talk about them.

30
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:18.560
So the first one let's
talk about is training.

31
00:01:18.560 --> 00:01:21.370
I think that one's a little
bit easier to understand.

32
00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:26.060
Training refers to basic training
on improving their skills.

33
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:30.150
We talked about Millenials wanting
to really focus on their strengths.

34
00:01:30.150 --> 00:01:34.040
And now let's talk about giving them
training to improve on these skills.

35
00:01:34.040 --> 00:01:38.890
There's a lot of companies that I talk to,
especially big corporate America,

36
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:42.880
Fortune 1000 companies that I talk to.

37
00:01:42.880 --> 00:01:46.630
They're not spending time
training their employees.

38
00:01:46.630 --> 00:01:49.240
They're not spending time
training their new hires.

39
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:51.570
A lot of entrepreneur do the same thing.

40
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:54.580
And let's be frank,
it's not really a good thing.

41
00:01:54.580 --> 00:01:56.960
We talk about training,
I'm sure a lot of you can relate to this.

42
00:01:56.960 --> 00:01:59.700
We bring on this new hire,
maybe a new sales person.

43
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:01.740
We're so excited to get them on board.

44
00:02:01.740 --> 00:02:03.720
They come on their first day.

45
00:02:03.720 --> 00:02:06.590
We give them this manual, if we have one,
with a whole bunch of stuff.

46
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:08.030
We kind of throw them,
here go to the room.

47
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:09.090
They lock themselves up in the room.

48
00:02:09.090 --> 00:02:10.190
We say, read the manual.

49
00:02:10.190 --> 00:02:13.310
They come back out, say all right great,
so, you got the information,

50
00:02:13.310 --> 00:02:14.510
you know what our products are all about.

51
00:02:14.510 --> 00:02:15.610
They say, yeah, yeah, I learned it.

52
00:02:15.610 --> 00:02:16.580
They say, okay, great.

53
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:18.240
Here's a stack of leads,
and start calling them.

54
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:20.450
What?

55
00:02:21.590 --> 00:02:25.600
This couldn't be farther
from what should be done.

56
00:02:25.600 --> 00:02:26.520
But we do it all the time.

57
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:29.533
I understand that everybody's busy,
I understand your managers are busy.

58
00:02:29.533 --> 00:02:34.416
But how will you expect your employees
to have success in whatever role

59
00:02:34.416 --> 00:02:38.410
you hired them if you're
not giving them training.

60
00:02:38.410 --> 00:02:41.570
>> And so, Javier, one of the things that
I've heard though from employers is well

61
00:02:41.570 --> 00:02:44.452
I don't want to invest in training for
this person because millennials,

62
00:02:44.452 --> 00:02:45.673
they switch jobs all the time.

63
00:02:45.673 --> 00:02:48.906
And the last thing I wanna do is send
this guy to this conference, and

64
00:02:48.906 --> 00:02:51.481
this conference and
then have him gone in six months.

65
00:02:51.481 --> 00:02:53.954
But, I think what we're saying here is,
on the flip side,

66
00:02:53.954 --> 00:02:56.780
if you don't do those things,
that maybe why you're losing them.

67
00:02:56.780 --> 00:02:59.960
So, it's kind of, they require
the training to wanna stay and

68
00:02:59.960 --> 00:03:02.840
that's what, it's kind of a catch 22.

69
00:03:02.840 --> 00:03:04.810
>> Yeah, I think that's funny and
it reminds me,

70
00:03:04.810 --> 00:03:10.160
I have actually a quote in my book where
we talk about, I mentioned a meme,

71
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:13.250
I think it's called where I saw on social
media when I was writing the book.

72
00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:17.420
And the meme says, the CEO and
the CFO of a company are talking.

73
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:20.620
And the CFO tells the CEO, hey,

74
00:03:20.620 --> 00:03:22.970
maybe we shouldn't invest the money
in training these people.

75
00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:26.320
What happens if we invest the money and
they leave us?

76
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:28.220
And the CEO turns around and
tells the CFO,

77
00:03:28.220 --> 00:03:32.600
well what happens if we don't and
they stay?

78
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:34.790
Which, you know,
puts this really into context.

79
00:03:34.790 --> 00:03:35.670
Right?

80
00:03:35.670 --> 00:03:36.890
So yeah, I get it.

81
00:03:36.890 --> 00:03:37.530
It's a risk.

82
00:03:37.530 --> 00:03:38.760
It's always a risk.

83
00:03:38.760 --> 00:03:40.550
Everything we do in business is a risk.

84
00:03:40.550 --> 00:03:43.400
When you hired that
person you took a risk.

85
00:03:43.400 --> 00:03:48.350
So my argument is,
if have your hiring process and

86
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:52.820
you hired this person, you've already
walked out the bigger risk part.

87
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:55.400
You've already taken the bigger
step in the journey.

88
00:03:55.400 --> 00:03:58.280
Now what you need to do is you
need to train that person, and

89
00:03:58.280 --> 00:04:03.180
give them all the tools and the knowledge
to be able to excel in their position.

90
00:04:03.180 --> 00:04:08.100
Why would you invest the money to hire
somebody then give them a half training or

91
00:04:08.100 --> 00:04:09.110
no training at all?

92
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:11.370
Expect them to read a book and
know how to do it,

93
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:13.930
that doesn't make any sense to me at all.

94
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:18.810
Corporate America is also prominent for
knowing, and this was very

95
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:22.520
popular with previous generations, and
now hopefully, it's happening less.

96
00:04:22.520 --> 00:04:25.510
But I still see it very
prominent in big companies,

97
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:30.560
where previous generations who have been
with companies for a while will tend to

98
00:04:30.560 --> 00:04:34.560
hold down some of their employees and
not teach them everything.

99
00:04:34.560 --> 00:04:37.760
You hold them down because you're
fearful that this new person,

100
00:04:37.760 --> 00:04:40.670
this younger person will
take away your job.

101
00:04:40.670 --> 00:04:45.060
So corporate America kind of created this
environment where don't teach the people

102
00:04:45.060 --> 00:04:48.860
under you everything because you might
lose your job to a younger employee.

103
00:04:48.860 --> 00:04:52.850
And that mindset creates a very,
very bad culture.

104
00:04:52.850 --> 00:04:56.111
If you talked to anybody who's ever
been in that receiving position,

105
00:04:56.111 --> 00:04:57.271
that's been held down,

106
00:04:57.271 --> 00:05:00.772
every single time they will tell you
that they were extremely frustrated.

107
00:05:00.772 --> 00:05:04.645
9 out of 10 times they quit their jobs
because they couldn't put up with it

108
00:05:04.645 --> 00:05:07.080
anymore and
you're holding down your talent.

109
00:05:07.080 --> 00:05:10.850
And that really comes from the culture
that you're creating in your environment.

110
00:05:10.850 --> 00:05:12.390
So what do we do?

111
00:05:12.390 --> 00:05:14.470
How do we get outside of that?

112
00:05:14.470 --> 00:05:16.335
Well as leaders we need
to put in systems and

113
00:05:16.335 --> 00:05:19.300
processes that really avoid this
type of errors from happening.

114
00:05:19.300 --> 00:05:23.480
I'll give you an example, in my company,
very strict from day one,

115
00:05:23.480 --> 00:05:26.100
any single person who ever
comes to interview for

116
00:05:26.100 --> 00:05:30.570
our position at our company, is told how
our philosophy in our company works.

117
00:05:30.570 --> 00:05:36.657
And the way it works in my company
is you will never get a promotion

118
00:05:36.657 --> 00:05:43.102
in my company until you train somebody
to do everything that you do.

119
00:05:43.102 --> 00:05:45.780
And you train somebody under you and
bring them up to do your job.

120
00:05:47.070 --> 00:05:49.330
That mindset is kind of
to a lot of people, and

121
00:05:49.330 --> 00:05:51.130
some people have a hard
time understanding that.

122
00:05:51.130 --> 00:05:54.230
But we create a culture where
it is your responsibility

123
00:05:54.230 --> 00:05:56.430
to coach somebody under you,
train somebody under you,

124
00:05:56.430 --> 00:06:00.650
teach them everything you know, all the
tips and tricks that they can do your job.

125
00:06:00.650 --> 00:06:03.560
And only when you've done
that will you be invited for

126
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:07.430
a promotion to a better position
in the company, a higher position.

127
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:13.000
Because at that point, we know,
I know that you coach, that you give back,

128
00:06:13.000 --> 00:06:15.560
and that you can promote your team and
you can coach your team.

129
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:18.490
If you don't have those abilities, and
you can't bring people up, you can't teach

130
00:06:18.490 --> 00:06:22.370
people new skills, there's no place for
you being promoted into our company.

131
00:06:22.370 --> 00:06:25.520
And I think that culture needs to
start permeating throughout most of

132
00:06:25.520 --> 00:06:26.260
corporate America.

133
00:06:26.260 --> 00:06:29.080
>> Right, and I think the key there with
that is to maybe do it across the board.

134
00:06:29.080 --> 00:06:31.870
Because if my boss came to me tomorrow and
said that, and

135
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:34.980
we'd never done that before,
I can maybe see the writing on the wall

136
00:06:34.980 --> 00:06:36.800
that I should start
getting my resume ready.

137
00:06:36.800 --> 00:06:40.460
But if you know coming in that this is
something that we all do and it's so

138
00:06:40.460 --> 00:06:41.660
that we can all work together.

139
00:06:41.660 --> 00:06:44.374
And I know that you're gonna
go on vacation someday and

140
00:06:44.374 --> 00:06:48.571
I'm gonna have to help you out, and that's
just a standard way your company works.

141
00:06:48.571 --> 00:06:50.820
Then I think they're gonna
get onboard with it.

142
00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:53.902
>> Yeah, I think that again,
it has to come from the leadership and

143
00:06:53.902 --> 00:06:56.484
just make it a policy
throughout the entire company.

144
00:06:56.484 --> 00:07:00.746
And just create that culture where
everybody is just naturally doing it on

145
00:07:00.746 --> 00:07:01.770
their own.

146
00:07:01.770 --> 00:07:03.875
I don't care what position
you are in our company,

147
00:07:03.875 --> 00:07:08.170
you need to be able to find
somebody who can do your job.

148
00:07:08.170 --> 00:07:10.510
That's how you will get promoted,
that's how you will you get better.

149
00:07:10.510 --> 00:07:16.350
That's when I know as the business leader
that you have mastered what your job is.

150
00:07:16.350 --> 00:07:19.740
Because until then, I don't feel
comfortable that you've mastered it.

151
00:07:19.740 --> 00:07:22.860
I think there's a lot of
ancient Chinese parables and

152
00:07:22.860 --> 00:07:24.270
whatnot that talk something about that.

153
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:28.070
But, the master has failed more times
than the beginner has ever tried.

154
00:07:28.070 --> 00:07:32.060
And you don't master something until
you can truly teach somebody to do it.

155
00:07:32.060 --> 00:07:33.850
So, for me, you can't ask me for

156
00:07:33.850 --> 00:07:36.380
a promotion until you've mastered
what you're currently doing.

157
00:07:36.380 --> 00:07:39.650
And the only way you show me that you've
mastered it is if you've trained somebody

158
00:07:39.650 --> 00:07:41.680
to fully be able to do what you do.

159
00:07:41.680 --> 00:07:44.230
And then you can grow into a better
position within our company.

160
00:07:44.230 --> 00:07:48.230
So this training is exactly what we need
to incorporate inside our companies today.

161
00:07:48.230 --> 00:07:52.370
>> Now does training for
millennial any different that training for

162
00:07:52.370 --> 00:07:53.998
baby boomers or gen X?

163
00:07:53.998 --> 00:07:58.470
Is there, we still talking about going
to conferences or other resources for

164
00:07:58.470 --> 00:07:59.610
a millennial?

165
00:07:59.610 --> 00:08:04.030
>> Yeah, so there is a little bit of a
difference, and I would break it down and

166
00:08:04.030 --> 00:08:05.910
we'll talk about this in a later segment.

167
00:08:05.910 --> 00:08:12.680
But the training is a little bit different
only in that millennials have a very short

168
00:08:12.680 --> 00:08:18.260
timeframe window and millennials are very
reserved about their brains space.

169
00:08:18.260 --> 00:08:23.220
So millennials don't necessarily want
to learn every single little thing.

170
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:27.710
They want to learn that where they
can find the information, and

171
00:08:27.710 --> 00:08:29.300
I think that's key.

172
00:08:29.300 --> 00:08:33.430
Previous generations I found want to learn
the minute details of how everything

173
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:35.440
works, and
how to answer every single question.

174
00:08:35.440 --> 00:08:38.390
And how to get everything before
they go out and do something,

175
00:08:38.390 --> 00:08:39.540
or a particular role.

176
00:08:39.540 --> 00:08:42.790
Millennials don't necessarily
want to know all the answers, but

177
00:08:42.790 --> 00:08:45.510
they want to know where they
can find all the answers.

178
00:08:45.510 --> 00:08:47.420
Very similar to being able to
Google something online and

179
00:08:47.420 --> 00:08:50.780
finding the answer,
they're used to that kind of mindset,

180
00:08:50.780 --> 00:08:54.950
they're used to that kind of culture,
and they want you to teach them.

181
00:08:54.950 --> 00:08:57.230
If I get stuck during
a sales presentation,

182
00:08:57.230 --> 00:08:59.660
where should I go find that answer?

183
00:08:59.660 --> 00:09:01.730
It's good to invest in the time and
saying, okay,

184
00:09:01.730 --> 00:09:03.680
these are all the possible objections,
right?

185
00:09:03.680 --> 00:09:07.470
But they don't need to learn to
memorize every single objection.

186
00:09:07.470 --> 00:09:09.480
They just say when I get stuck,
teach me where to go.

187
00:09:09.480 --> 00:09:12.460
>> So maybe in the past if we were
talking about hey, I have an issue,

188
00:09:12.460 --> 00:09:15.460
I need some help with that,
you might schedule a trainer to come in.

189
00:09:15.460 --> 00:09:18.230
And that might be three, six weeks out.

190
00:09:18.230 --> 00:09:22.305
Maybe one of the things we look for
now is here are some online resources, and

191
00:09:22.305 --> 00:09:26.189
knowledge bases, or groups of other
people that do similar positions,

192
00:09:26.189 --> 00:09:29.394
like on LinkedIn, that you can find and
join those things.

193
00:09:29.394 --> 00:09:32.443
So going back to the point we talked
about in a previous episodes of instant

194
00:09:32.443 --> 00:09:33.190
gratification.

195
00:09:33.190 --> 00:09:35.760
If I have a problem I can
get an answer now, and

196
00:09:35.760 --> 00:09:37.620
I'm not waiting six weeks to do my job.

197
00:09:37.620 --> 00:09:38.260
>> Yeah, exactly.

198
00:09:38.260 --> 00:09:44.360
And when I talk about reserve brain space,
I was saying when I was growing up,

199
00:09:44.360 --> 00:09:49.350
again in the Gen X mindset,
we didn't have cell phones.

200
00:09:49.350 --> 00:09:51.720
And the concept of like a phone book,

201
00:09:51.720 --> 00:09:56.020
we would pride ourselves in In memorizing
people's phone numbers, or having a very

202
00:09:56.020 --> 00:10:00.050
good little complete little black book
with everybody's phone numbers in it.

203
00:10:00.050 --> 00:10:02.930
Millennials have no interest
in memorizing phone numbers.

204
00:10:02.930 --> 00:10:03.850
And that's the perfect example for

205
00:10:03.850 --> 00:10:06.810
me to get you to understand that
that's how they reserve their brains.

206
00:10:06.810 --> 00:10:10.250
They say, why in the world would I
memorize people's phone numbers?

207
00:10:10.250 --> 00:10:11.410
>> If I didn't have my phone and

208
00:10:11.410 --> 00:10:13.600
I had to call someone,
I don't know what would happen.

209
00:10:13.600 --> 00:10:17.872
I think I would be able to call my
parents, and that's about the end of it.

210
00:10:17.872 --> 00:10:19.756
Yeah, but before cell phones and

211
00:10:19.756 --> 00:10:23.792
before this kind of information was
readily available to us all the time

212
00:10:23.792 --> 00:10:27.907
because we can find our phone numbers
in our cell phone whenever we want.

213
00:10:27.907 --> 00:10:32.709
But before that was the case we would fill
our brain, whatever brain capacity we

214
00:10:32.709 --> 00:10:36.530
had available we would fill
a lot of it with phone numbers.

215
00:10:36.530 --> 00:10:38.250
Because that's just how we wired.

216
00:10:38.250 --> 00:10:42.480
Millenials are so keen to say why would I
put all those phone numbers in my head?

217
00:10:42.480 --> 00:10:43.710
Doesn't make any sense.

218
00:10:43.710 --> 00:10:46.600
They want to know, okay, so
to get that information,

219
00:10:46.600 --> 00:10:50.230
to get those phone numbers, I go to my
cell phone and I have it all there.

220
00:10:50.230 --> 00:10:53.820
I go to my contacts in my Outlook and
my Gmail or wherever and

221
00:10:53.820 --> 00:10:55.610
I can access that information.

222
00:10:55.610 --> 00:10:59.260
Very, very,
similar to explain about the training.

223
00:10:59.260 --> 00:11:00.700
We don't need to give
them all the answers.

224
00:11:00.700 --> 00:11:02.830
We need to go over some basic things,
basic skills,

225
00:11:02.830 --> 00:11:04.950
do some role play, train them correctly.

226
00:11:04.950 --> 00:11:08.690
And then teach them, say if you get stuck
this is where you go for the resources.

227
00:11:08.690 --> 00:11:12.200
Either a group, an online resource, and we
need to invest the time in creating those.

228
00:11:12.200 --> 00:11:16.130
And the second part of it real quick,
is going to be the mentorship.

229
00:11:16.130 --> 00:11:17.390
So we talked a lot about training.

230
00:11:17.390 --> 00:11:20.305
Mentorship is very close to training.

231
00:11:20.305 --> 00:11:24.445
However it is actually having kind
of like a partner, or group, or

232
00:11:24.445 --> 00:11:25.982
a program in your company.

233
00:11:25.982 --> 00:11:27.760
As someone within the company.

234
00:11:27.760 --> 00:11:29.309
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yes, within the company

235
00:11:29.309 --> 00:11:32.715
that can give that millennial mentorship.

236
00:11:32.715 --> 00:11:35.549
And when we talked about it,
it's just kind of a form of training but

237
00:11:35.549 --> 00:11:37.155
it's an important part of training.

238
00:11:37.155 --> 00:11:39.085
Millennials want to be developed.

239
00:11:39.085 --> 00:11:42.010
Millennials want to follow a leader.

240
00:11:42.010 --> 00:11:44.490
And they want a mentor to
teach them those things.

241
00:11:44.490 --> 00:11:46.470
So, I highly recommend,
in our company we do it,

242
00:11:46.470 --> 00:11:50.590
new hires always are assigned
somebody that they can learn from.

243
00:11:50.590 --> 00:11:56.890
Most companies, you wanna put your new
hires right next to your best performer.

244
00:11:56.890 --> 00:11:59.550
You don't put them down to the lowest
performer because he's the least busy.

245
00:11:59.550 --> 00:12:02.870
No, you put him next to the best
performer, any new hire, millennial or

246
00:12:02.870 --> 00:12:06.420
not because you want him to learn
the skills, the abilities and

247
00:12:06.420 --> 00:12:08.670
the habits that your
top performer is doing.

248
00:12:08.670 --> 00:12:13.080
You can't put him next to the guy that
is less busy because he has more time,

249
00:12:13.080 --> 00:12:14.640
that just makes absolutely no sense.

250
00:12:14.640 --> 00:12:16.060
He is going to learn the bad habits,

251
00:12:16.060 --> 00:12:19.140
he is going to learn the things that
make this person your bottom performer.

252
00:12:19.140 --> 00:12:22.560
So if you want to be the best
performer team them up with a mentor

253
00:12:22.560 --> 00:12:24.550
that gets the results that you want.

254
00:12:24.550 --> 00:12:28.050
Your top performer that's who need
to be paired up with all your hires

255
00:12:28.050 --> 00:12:28.930
including millennials.

256
00:12:28.930 --> 00:12:31.180
And millennials really create
that kind of mentorship.

257
00:12:31.180 --> 00:12:32.820
They want that kind of relationship.

258
00:12:32.820 --> 00:12:34.704
Again, it's about building
the relationships at work,

259
00:12:34.704 --> 00:12:36.364
it's about being friends
with your co-workers.

260
00:12:36.364 --> 00:12:40.113
This mentorship allows them to connect
on a a different level about learning

261
00:12:40.113 --> 00:12:43.160
the same material, so
it's not just going to a class.

262
00:12:43.160 --> 00:12:45.260
Get them to a class,
then team them up with somebody or

263
00:12:45.260 --> 00:12:47.060
in a group where they can
have this kind of mentorship.

264
00:12:47.060 --> 00:12:49.630
And that's gonna set your
millenials up for success.

265
00:12:49.630 --> 00:12:52.530
And that's one of the things that they're
looking for in the workplace today.

266
00:12:52.530 --> 00:12:55.470
>> And a mentor can not only help
you with those specific job skills.

267
00:12:55.470 --> 00:12:58.974
But also when you come to a new
company there's processes and

268
00:12:58.974 --> 00:13:00.560
procedures to figure out.

269
00:13:00.560 --> 00:13:04.110
And it's great to have that person to go
to that's been there for a few years, and

270
00:13:04.110 --> 00:13:07.290
can really help guide you
in your new position.

271
00:13:07.290 --> 00:13:10.460
So I think that's a great point for
us to go ahead and cut off,

272
00:13:10.460 --> 00:13:11.710
unless you've got some
more information here.

273
00:13:11.710 --> 00:13:13.460
>> Yep,
no that's pretty much it all right there.

274
00:13:13.460 --> 00:13:14.197
>> Fantastic.
All right so

275
00:13:14.197 --> 00:13:16.393
we've got a lot more great
content in the book to cover,

276
00:13:16.393 --> 00:13:17.669
a lot more episodes after this.

277
00:13:17.669 --> 00:13:21.470
So be sure to stay tuned, but for
now signing off, I'm Peter VanRysdam.

278
00:13:21.470 --> 00:13:23.510
>> And
I'm Javier Montez your millennial expert.

279
00:13:23.510 --> 00:13:25.706
See you at the next episode.

280
00:13:25.706 --> 00:13:35.706
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Collaborative Work Environments
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.456
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.456 --> 00:00:05.970
Hello and welcome to the show.

3
00:00:05.970 --> 00:00:07.370
I'm your host, Peter VanRysdam and

4
00:00:07.370 --> 00:00:10.630
today we are continuing in our series
in talking about millennials in

5
00:00:10.630 --> 00:00:14.180
the workplace, and specifically what
they look for in the workplace.

6
00:00:14.180 --> 00:00:16.320
And here to help us we have the expert,

7
00:00:16.320 --> 00:00:19.140
the man who wrote the book
Millennial Workforce, Javier Montes.

8
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:20.200
Javier, how you doing today?

9
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:22.580
>> I'm doing fantastic Peter,
thank you very much for having me.

10
00:00:22.580 --> 00:00:25.420
Pleasure to be here again,
talking about my favorite topic,

11
00:00:25.420 --> 00:00:27.850
millennials in the workforce.

12
00:00:27.850 --> 00:00:32.235
>> And I know today we've got a unique
one we're talking about the work place

13
00:00:32.235 --> 00:00:36.055
environment itself and what that looks
like, so where do we start on that.

14
00:00:36.055 --> 00:00:40.187
>> So a topic we're gonna talk about
today is what millennials are looking for

15
00:00:40.187 --> 00:00:41.245
in the workplace.

16
00:00:41.245 --> 00:00:46.495
The topic for today is going to be they
want a collaborative work environment.

17
00:00:46.495 --> 00:00:50.154
>> Now are we talking about those
kinda open rooms where everyone's in

18
00:00:50.154 --> 00:00:51.062
the same place?

19
00:00:51.062 --> 00:00:55.313
Or are you saying more places where
they can go to meeting rooms and

20
00:00:55.313 --> 00:00:57.250
get together or both?

21
00:00:57.250 --> 00:01:02.600
>> A little of both, I think when I wrote
this portion of the book, I'm really

22
00:01:02.600 --> 00:01:08.350
referring to a team oriented kind of
culture that really works together.

23
00:01:08.350 --> 00:01:11.330
What I've found in big
corporate America is that,

24
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:15.370
aside from the departments really
separating the company itself,

25
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:19.860
a lot of the departments themselves inside
the departments are a little disconnected.

26
00:01:19.860 --> 00:01:22.630
And I think that people
are working on things,

27
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:25.590
but they're not necessarily
working on things together.

28
00:01:25.590 --> 00:01:28.639
And a lot of companies they
put people in cubicles and

29
00:01:28.639 --> 00:01:31.143
they expect them to
just work on their own.

30
00:01:31.143 --> 00:01:35.300
Because big corporate America previous
generational thinking has conditioned

31
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:38.233
them to believe that if they're
talking to their peers or

32
00:01:38.233 --> 00:01:43.330
if they're with their peers, that they're
distracted and they're not producing.

33
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:47.840
So what's happened is that
millennials are looking for

34
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:51.870
a work environment where
they can collaborate with

35
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:56.930
teams within their organization that
work together to produce a common good.

36
00:01:56.930 --> 00:02:00.720
And I think that millennials right now
are really seeking that in the workplace.

37
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:03.640
They want a company that really promotes
this type of culture where we work

38
00:02:03.640 --> 00:02:08.630
together, we can collaborate on teams just
like we did when we were in school to

39
00:02:08.630 --> 00:02:11.760
really put together these amazing
projects and have amazing results.

40
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:16.711
I think the concept of the greater,
I think the saying is,

41
00:02:16.711 --> 00:02:20.740
the sum of its parts is-
>> Yeah,

42
00:02:20.740 --> 00:02:23.760
greater than the sums of its parts, yeah.

43
00:02:23.760 --> 00:02:27.140
>> The collective of all of us is greater
than the sum of all of our efforts,

44
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:28.430
basically, right?

45
00:02:28.430 --> 00:02:32.262
So what that means to say is that one,
plus one, plus one,

46
00:02:32.262 --> 00:02:34.550
plus one is not necessarily four.

47
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:39.199
But one, plus one, plus one,
plus one is probably ten, or 40, right?

48
00:02:39.199 --> 00:02:42.350
That concept, millennials are very,
very clear on that.

49
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:45.320
They understand that just
because I can produce one,

50
00:02:46.330 --> 00:02:51.060
the four of us together we're gonna
produce way more than four, right?

51
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:52.330
That concept is really key, and

52
00:02:52.330 --> 00:02:56.300
they're looking to really collaborate
with teams inside our organizations.

53
00:02:56.300 --> 00:02:57.870
They want this team environment.

54
00:02:57.870 --> 00:03:00.560
So in essence,
they don't want to win individually,

55
00:03:00.560 --> 00:03:02.040
I think it's a big difference, right?

56
00:03:02.040 --> 00:03:04.850
Previous generations were all about me,
me, me, me, and I want to win

57
00:03:04.850 --> 00:03:08.030
individually, and it's all about me and
I'm trying to win the big prize.

58
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:10.930
millennials are more focused on,
how can we win as a team?

59
00:03:10.930 --> 00:03:12.062
How can we win as a department?

60
00:03:12.062 --> 00:03:13.620
How can we win as a company?

61
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:16.460
Because we're part of
this collaborative unit.

62
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:19.885
>> And I remember the first time I
toured one of these open offices

63
00:03:19.885 --> 00:03:24.185
years ago here in Florida, and
my question was, isn't it distracting?

64
00:03:24.185 --> 00:03:27.612
You got this guy talking and this guy
talking, and does that get in your head?

65
00:03:27.612 --> 00:03:28.395
And they said,

66
00:03:28.395 --> 00:03:32.640
you know what we've found is we have
what they called creative collisions.

67
00:03:32.640 --> 00:03:35.752
Which is basically, two people might be
having a conversation, and this guy can

68
00:03:35.752 --> 00:03:38.849
hear it, but this guy might have something
to add that they didn't know about.

69
00:03:38.849 --> 00:03:42.100
Or hey, you know I've been working on that
all day too, I can help you out with that.

70
00:03:42.100 --> 00:03:46.070
Or no, we've already got this done,
let me show you.

71
00:03:46.070 --> 00:03:48.857
And those things aren't gonna happen
if you're going in someone's office

72
00:03:48.857 --> 00:03:51.520
to have this conversation, and
it's not public and you can't hear it.

73
00:03:51.520 --> 00:03:54.329
So I think it's a great
way to get collaboration

74
00:03:54.329 --> 00:03:56.868
if you didn't even know you were missing.

75
00:03:56.868 --> 00:04:01.479
>> Yeah definitely, and
again this goes back to the leadership,and

76
00:04:01.479 --> 00:04:05.926
really leaning on the leadership
to put together these teams and

77
00:04:05.926 --> 00:04:11.467
encourage the team to really get together
and contribute to the overall cause.

78
00:04:11.467 --> 00:04:13.591
In leadership, the management team and

79
00:04:13.591 --> 00:04:17.970
the companies has to promote this culture
of let's get together and put together.

80
00:04:17.970 --> 00:04:22.455
Like brainstorming sessions are a great
idea, a common work space is a great idea.

81
00:04:22.455 --> 00:04:27.345
And really facilitating the spaces
in your office to be able to

82
00:04:27.345 --> 00:04:29.535
create this team environment is critical.

83
00:04:29.535 --> 00:04:33.930
We talk about companies like Google who
have beanbags in their offices, and

84
00:04:33.930 --> 00:04:37.600
they have these what I call them culture
rooms where it's all about their culture.

85
00:04:37.600 --> 00:04:39.980
And they can kind of just hang out and
really elaborate.

86
00:04:39.980 --> 00:04:43.390
They have brainstorming rooms with
whiteboard paint on the walls and

87
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:45.080
they just write crazy ideas.

88
00:04:45.080 --> 00:04:50.925
And that kind of environment
really allows the millennials and

89
00:04:50.925 --> 00:04:54.010
non-millennials to throw ideas out.

90
00:04:54.010 --> 00:04:55.970
And it's a safe space, nothing's wrong.

91
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:57.750
There's no stupid ideas here.

92
00:04:57.750 --> 00:05:00.050
Because that is what triggers
innovative thinking and

93
00:05:00.050 --> 00:05:02.430
that's what moves our society forward.

94
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:05.360
And that's what can really trigger
our corporations, our companies,

95
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:10.380
our entrepreneurs to really expand and

96
00:05:10.380 --> 00:05:13.670
really be able to create amazing
things that we haven't thought about,

97
00:05:13.670 --> 00:05:16.280
if we allow for
that type of collaboration.

98
00:05:16.280 --> 00:05:19.837
>> Now this sounds a little bit like it
could go, or kind of flying in the face of

99
00:05:19.837 --> 00:05:23.112
something we talked about in
a previous episode of telecommuting and

100
00:05:23.112 --> 00:05:26.725
something that's important for a lot
of millennial's to be able to work may

101
00:05:26.725 --> 00:05:29.908
be a little different schedules or
a little different locations.

102
00:05:29.908 --> 00:05:33.555
But we can still create team environments
even when we telecommute through apps and

103
00:05:33.555 --> 00:05:35.380
things like that, is that right?

104
00:05:35.380 --> 00:05:37.590
>> Yeah of course, I mean there's so
much technology out there right now,

105
00:05:37.590 --> 00:05:38.980
you can still create
that team environment.

106
00:05:38.980 --> 00:05:42.365
I know a lot of companies who have remote
people who work in different parts

107
00:05:42.365 --> 00:05:44.450
of the country, and
we still come together.

108
00:05:44.450 --> 00:05:47.475
I mean, there's a lot of companies that
do this, I call them a daily huddle,

109
00:05:47.475 --> 00:05:49.650
some people call them a daily stand-up.

110
00:05:49.650 --> 00:05:52.950
And you really create alignment as a team,
right?

111
00:05:52.950 --> 00:05:55.580
There's so many other companies
that I go and I visit,

112
00:05:55.580 --> 00:05:58.690
and I talk to and
the team never comes together.

113
00:05:58.690 --> 00:06:00.680
The team never aligns on
what they're doing or

114
00:06:00.680 --> 00:06:01.745
what they're trying to accomplish.

115
00:06:01.745 --> 00:06:04.978
So you get again what we talked
about in a previous episode, you get

116
00:06:04.978 --> 00:06:08.808
people pulling in different directions and
the alignment's just not there.

117
00:06:08.808 --> 00:06:09.588
>> Right.
>> We're trying

118
00:06:09.588 --> 00:06:12.110
to move the ship in one direction,
the captain, the CEO,

119
00:06:12.110 --> 00:06:16.140
the entrepreneur, the leader is
saying hey, we're gonna go that way.

120
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:19.600
But the rest of the team either doesn't
hear it, and they say well, I'm working

121
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:22.740
really fast, I'm working really fast, but
if you're pulling the opposite way of

122
00:06:22.740 --> 00:06:25.620
the rest of the team,
well we can't get anywhere, right?

123
00:06:25.620 --> 00:06:27.220
You're pulling against
where we're trying to go.

124
00:06:27.220 --> 00:06:31.140
So the alignment is so critical just
to move forward an organization.

125
00:06:31.140 --> 00:06:32.670
The bigger a company gets,

126
00:06:32.670 --> 00:06:35.190
the bigger an organization gets
the more challenging that becomes.

127
00:06:35.190 --> 00:06:39.110
Because it's very easy to create team
members that start disconnecting,

128
00:06:39.110 --> 00:06:41.180
departments that start disconnecting.

129
00:06:41.180 --> 00:06:43.326
You need really, really strong ties, and

130
00:06:43.326 --> 00:06:46.496
strong systems and
processes to really keep the team aligned.

131
00:06:46.496 --> 00:06:49.065
And I think that millennials
are really looking for

132
00:06:49.065 --> 00:06:51.941
a company that embodies this
team environment, right?

133
00:06:51.941 --> 00:06:54.670
Putting it out there with your
core values is very important.

134
00:06:54.670 --> 00:06:57.660
And, when a millennial joins a team,
and they come on board,

135
00:06:57.660 --> 00:06:59.360
they want to feel like
they're part of a team.

136
00:06:59.360 --> 00:07:02.354
They don't want to feel like,
i'm just one person in this company.

137
00:07:02.354 --> 00:07:06.841
Yeah I do a job, yes I have purpose or
whatever, but i'm alone, I'm stuck in

138
00:07:06.841 --> 00:07:10.652
a cubicle and I wanna collaborate
with somebody that I work with.

139
00:07:10.652 --> 00:07:14.142
But when I try to, the boss comes in and
tells me, hey what are you doing,

140
00:07:14.142 --> 00:07:17.290
why are you guys you know talking so
much or what not, right?

141
00:07:17.290 --> 00:07:20.610
That kind of environment is
not conducive for millennials.

142
00:07:20.610 --> 00:07:23.060
I would say it's not conducive for
any generation as well.

143
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:26.337
But previous generations have
had these blinders on and say,

144
00:07:26.337 --> 00:07:29.865
this is the way that it needs to be
because if you deviate from that,

145
00:07:29.865 --> 00:07:32.023
then your team is not being productive.

146
00:07:32.023 --> 00:07:35.651
>> Yeah, and even if you are in separate
spaces, either geographically or

147
00:07:35.651 --> 00:07:39.990
you're in an environment where they have
walls and you can't break them down.

148
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:43.000
Staying, communicating with things
like Skype, things like Slack.

149
00:07:43.000 --> 00:07:46.680
I've even seen teams on video together
in Google hangouts throughout the day,

150
00:07:46.680 --> 00:07:49.340
even though they're spread out across
the country or across the world.

151
00:07:49.340 --> 00:07:52.100
And so that's definitely
important to get that atmosphere,

152
00:07:52.100 --> 00:07:53.710
regardless of how your company is set up.

153
00:07:53.710 --> 00:07:56.246
But any other final thoughts on
this topic before we move on?

154
00:07:56.246 --> 00:08:00.144
>> Nope, just being collaborative and
creating that team environment, right?

155
00:08:00.144 --> 00:08:02.208
Team, I mean I use the acronym
all the time at my company,

156
00:08:02.208 --> 00:08:03.820
together everyone achieves more.

157
00:08:03.820 --> 00:08:06.340
I also use that there's no I in team.

158
00:08:06.340 --> 00:08:08.071
We use that and we talk about it a lot.

159
00:08:08.071 --> 00:08:11.124
And that's critical, just keep that in
mind when it comes to millennials, and

160
00:08:11.124 --> 00:08:13.152
keep it in mind when it comes
to your team in general.

161
00:08:13.152 --> 00:08:17.005
I think everybody in an organisation,
regardless of what generation they're from

162
00:08:17.005 --> 00:08:20.110
will really find value when you
can create that harmony, and

163
00:08:20.110 --> 00:08:23.230
that sense of belonging to
something bigger than yourself.

164
00:08:23.230 --> 00:08:24.465
>> What was that team acronym again?

165
00:08:24.465 --> 00:08:27.329
Cuz that was a lot easier than
the sum of your parts equals the-

166
00:08:27.329 --> 00:08:28.900
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, team, team,

167
00:08:28.900 --> 00:08:30.680
together, everyone achieves more.

168
00:08:30.680 --> 00:08:33.430
>> That's great, and I think that's
kinda the whole point there.

169
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:35.448
So great information on that one, and

170
00:08:35.448 --> 00:08:39.622
I know we've got a lot more information
to cover in some future episodes here.

171
00:08:39.622 --> 00:08:40.930
So we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

172
00:08:40.930 --> 00:08:42.070
I'm Peter VanRysdam.

173
00:08:42.070 --> 00:08:44.130
>> And I'm Javier Montes,
your millennial expert.

174
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:44.905
See you next episode.

175
00:08:44.905 --> 00:08:46.091
Bye-bye.

176

WEBVTT

1

I am your host Peter VanRysdam and

00:00:07.520 --> 00:00:10.990
today we're continuing in our series

00:00:10.990 --> 00:00:15.510
in the work place, specifically, we have a
great episode right now about having fun.

6
00:00:15.510 --> 00:00:19.150
I'm really excited to talk about this and
here to help us and understand

7
00:00:19.150 --> 00:00:22.745
how we have fun professionally is the man
who wrote the book Millennial Workforce,

8
00:00:22.745 --> 00:00:24.850
Javier Montes, Javier, how you doing?

9
00:00:24.850 --> 00:00:26.170
>> I'm doing fantastic, Peter.

10
00:00:26.170 --> 00:00:27.560
Thank you very much for
having me on the show.

11
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:29.480
I'm excited to chat with
you today a little bit.

12
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:32.270
We're gonna talk about my favorite topic.

13
00:00:32.270 --> 00:00:33.480
Guess what that is?

14
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:34.730
>> Fun, I hope.

15
00:00:34.730 --> 00:00:36.910
>> Close, it's about Millenials.

16
00:00:36.910 --> 00:00:38.210
>> Millenials.
Come on, we're [INAUDIBLE] away.

17
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:39.440
Fun with Millenials.

18
00:00:39.440 --> 00:00:40.890
>> There you go.

19
00:00:40.890 --> 00:00:41.910
>> You were like half right.

20
00:00:41.910 --> 00:00:45.410
>> [LAUGH] So what do we mean when we say,
let me have fun.

21
00:00:45.410 --> 00:00:49.370
>> So this concept is like what do
Millennial's want in the workplace?

22
00:00:49.370 --> 00:00:51.950
What are they looking for
when deciding on a place to work?

23
00:00:51.950 --> 00:00:55.160
And one of the things that they
are looking for, is they want to have fun.

24
00:00:55.160 --> 00:00:58.730
They want a company that lets them and
encourages them to have fun.

25
00:00:58.730 --> 00:01:02.180
So this concept,
it's pretty self explanatory.

26
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:04.990
But I think what we're going to talk
about today is really how can we

27
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:07.610
incorporate that into our
professional work environment.

28
00:01:07.610 --> 00:01:10.310
I think that's the challenge that I
get from most entrepreneur, right?

29
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:15.825
We say, yeah, we'd love to make our work
fun, but we got a we got to deal with,

30
00:01:15.825 --> 00:01:19.585
we have a challenge, because we
still need people to be serious.

31
00:01:19.585 --> 00:01:23.345
I can't have people just going crazy and
running amuck.

32
00:01:23.345 --> 00:01:25.585
So, how do we incorporate
fun into the workplace?

33
00:01:25.585 --> 00:01:28.245
I think that's the challenge, so
let's address that right now.

34
00:01:28.245 --> 00:01:31.075
So, Millennials,
why do they wanna have fun at work?

35
00:01:31.075 --> 00:01:34.210
I mean,
besides the obvious reason of having fun

36
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:37.430
we gotta remember that Millennials
have their personal life and

37
00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:40.370
their work like intertwined
into one thing, right?

38
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:45.530
So if it's one thing, just we can think
about, it's their one life, and they want

39
00:01:45.530 --> 00:01:50.000
to make sure that their priority is taken
care of, and their priority is happiness.

40
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:52.080
They want to enjoy life now.

41
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:55.030
Remember, Millennials don't want
to wait to enjoy life later on,

42
00:01:55.030 --> 00:01:56.290
they wanna enjoy it right now.

43
00:01:56.290 --> 00:01:58.430
The experience that they're
getting while working for

44
00:01:58.430 --> 00:02:02.840
our company, they want it to be fun
because that's their life, it's one life.

45
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:04.430
There's no personal life and
work life, right?

46
00:02:04.430 --> 00:02:08.130
They don't have this segregation of
in my personal life I have fun, and

47
00:02:08.130 --> 00:02:10.690
then in my work life it's
okay not to have fun.

48
00:02:10.690 --> 00:02:11.810
It's one thing for them.

49
00:02:11.810 --> 00:02:15.220
So in their mindset,
it's let's just enjoy life.

50
00:02:15.220 --> 00:02:15.900
Let's have fun.

51
00:02:15.900 --> 00:02:16.800
Let's enjoy it.

52
00:02:16.800 --> 00:02:18.730
So part of that is enjoying
naturally what you're doing.

53
00:02:18.730 --> 00:02:22.370
But the other part is,
are we creating a culture in our companies

54
00:02:22.370 --> 00:02:25.510
where our team can enjoy and
have a little bit of fun?

55
00:02:26.710 --> 00:02:27.680
All right.
So how can we do that?

56
00:02:27.680 --> 00:02:28.550
Let's talk about some ideas.

57
00:02:28.550 --> 00:02:31.950
So I'll talk about some personal
experiences on what we do in our company,

58
00:02:31.950 --> 00:02:33.370
on how we incorporate fun.

59
00:02:33.370 --> 00:02:36.000
So one of the things that we do in
our company is birthdays, right?

60
00:02:36.000 --> 00:02:39.180
Birthdays are a huge
celebration at my company.

61
00:02:39.180 --> 00:02:42.990
I mean, we talk almost an entire
day to almost disconnect

62
00:02:42.990 --> 00:02:45.400
from everything we do whenever
somebody celebrates a birthday.

63
00:02:45.400 --> 00:02:48.410
Now, as your company gets bigger you
can do it per person, but you may take

64
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:52.730
one day in your company or half a day to
celebrate all the birthdays in that month.

65
00:02:52.730 --> 00:02:54.550
You can do something like that.

66
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:56.010
Now, what would
a celebration in our company

67
00:02:56.010 --> 00:02:57.280
look like when somebody
celebrates a birthday.

68
00:02:57.280 --> 00:02:59.830
Well, first thing is we try
to catch them off guard.

69
00:02:59.830 --> 00:03:00.890
How do we catch them off guard?

70
00:03:00.890 --> 00:03:04.170
Well, if you're celebrating a birthday on
Thursday, maybe we'll start celebrating on

71
00:03:04.170 --> 00:03:06.930
Wednesday, maybe we'll
surprise you on Tuesday.

72
00:03:06.930 --> 00:03:09.980
Sometimes well be really evil and
we'll do it on Friday,

73
00:03:09.980 --> 00:03:12.200
make you think we forgot your birthday,
right?

74
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:14.320
So we'll do things like that,
that kind of makes it a little fun.

75
00:03:14.320 --> 00:03:15.650
So you get surprised on your birthday.

76
00:03:15.650 --> 00:03:17.060
So what kind of surprise do you get?

77
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:19.650
Well, when you walk into the office,
guess what happens?

78
00:03:19.650 --> 00:03:21.130
Everybody starts screaming and
cheering and

79
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:23.370
we play loud music when
you walk into the office.

80
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:26.550
Everybody is saying happy birthday, and
immediately after we start cheering and

81
00:03:26.550 --> 00:03:27.285
screaming, guess what?

82
00:03:27.285 --> 00:03:30.850
Somebody's coming out from the kitchen
with a birthday cake, candles lit.

83
00:03:30.850 --> 00:03:32.430
Now, typically are not regular candles,

84
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:35.670
typically we have these firework
candles that are super huge.

85
00:03:35.670 --> 00:03:37.365
You have seen them on TV all the time.

86
00:03:37.365 --> 00:03:38.770
>> Yeah.
>> So something crazy like that that you

87
00:03:38.770 --> 00:03:41.150
can't blow out,
then we sing happy birthday.

88
00:03:41.150 --> 00:03:42.870
After that,
the person walks to their desk.

89
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:46.900
The desk is typically decorated with all
kinds of confetti and all kinds of crazy

90
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:50.050
stuff, streamers hanging from the ceiling,
streamers hanging from their chairs.

91
00:03:50.050 --> 00:03:53.200
I mean it's just a really fun and
festive time.

92
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:56.780
We typically spend maybe a little morning
time kind of doing a little bit of work,

93
00:03:56.780 --> 00:03:57.830
catching up, kind of wrapping up.

94
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:01.190
But we understand that when lunch time
comes around, we're pretty much gonna

95
00:04:01.190 --> 00:04:03.730
disconnect from there to the rest of
the day, I mean that's just our company.

96
00:04:03.730 --> 00:04:05.150
And what do we do?

97
00:04:05.150 --> 00:04:08.210
Then we'll typically go and find some
lunch, go out to eat somewhere or

98
00:04:08.210 --> 00:04:11.740
we'll order lunch in, typically what
that person's favorite food is.

99
00:04:11.740 --> 00:04:16.580
And then from there, we'll go to an
offsite and do some kind of fun activity.

100
00:04:16.580 --> 00:04:20.090
A fun activity we could talk about,
we'd go bowling, we go skating.

101
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:23.000
We do things that are typically gonna
be kinda team building activities, but

102
00:04:23.000 --> 00:04:24.010
at the same time it's fun.

103
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:24.950
We're there to disconnect.

104
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:27.350
We're there to have fun and
celebrate somebody's birthday.

105
00:04:27.350 --> 00:04:31.260
And again, these are the kind of things
which we incorporate into our company

106
00:04:31.260 --> 00:04:35.560
because part of our core values
in my company is have fun.

107
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:40.690
>> Yeah, when we talk about the family
atmosphere of the company nowadays and

108
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:41.850
that's something you do as a family.

109
00:04:41.850 --> 00:04:43.290
You celebrate birthdays and

110
00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:48.020
it's not something you do at work
in the old way of doing things.

111
00:04:48.020 --> 00:04:50.188
And maybe the birthday thing
isn't the right thing for

112
00:04:50.188 --> 00:04:53.342
your company like you said, it could be
too many people or something like that,

113
00:04:53.342 --> 00:04:55.830
but find those things that
you can do that are fun.

114
00:04:55.830 --> 00:04:58.690
>> Yeah, I mean it's just
an example of what works, right?

115
00:04:58.690 --> 00:05:01.950
I think that everything that we've
talked about, everything that we talk

116
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:05.410
about in my book, really revolves around
what's right for your company, right?

117
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:06.840
What's your culture like?

118
00:05:06.840 --> 00:05:10.100
What does your culture call for
for your culture?

119
00:05:10.100 --> 00:05:11.270
It has to stay true to you.

120
00:05:11.270 --> 00:05:15.340
These things can't be forced, they can't
be faked because then you'll lose theme.

121
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:17.010
It's immediately ineffective.

122
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:21.200
So just think about ideas of
what you can incorporate into

123
00:05:21.200 --> 00:05:22.171
your company that'll be fun.

124
00:05:22.171 --> 00:05:23.500
I mean I'll give you another example,

125
00:05:23.500 --> 00:05:27.230
just to be kinda quick on what
other ideas you can incorporate.

126
00:05:27.230 --> 00:05:28.740
So we have our weekly meeting.

127
00:05:28.740 --> 00:05:29.960
We've talked about that.

128
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:34.050
And at our weekly meeting, there's a part

129
00:05:34.050 --> 00:05:37.980
to recognize one of our team members for
something that they've done.

130
00:05:37.980 --> 00:05:41.370
Now typically in our company what we have
to do is during that recognition is peer

131
00:05:41.370 --> 00:05:42.570
to peer recognition.

132
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:45.760
You could recognize somebody who's
done something to help you, but

133
00:05:45.760 --> 00:05:48.070
it has to be tied to
one of our core values.

134
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:51.980
So you say, well Peter you exemplified
our core value of live by excellence and

135
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:54.070
Peter did this by helping me,
this, this, or that.

136
00:05:54.070 --> 00:05:58.680
And he really went above and beyond for
our client and made XYZ happen.

137
00:05:58.680 --> 00:05:59.380
All right, everybody.

138
00:05:59.380 --> 00:06:00.010
Cheers.
Way to go, Peter.

139
00:06:00.010 --> 00:06:01.700
>> Thank you.
>> And now comes the fun.

140
00:06:01.700 --> 00:06:05.470
The fun comes in that we give
every time you get recognized for

141
00:06:05.470 --> 00:06:08.750
one of our core values you come
up to the front of the room.

142
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:10.910
We have a basketball hoop
with a basketball and

143
00:06:10.910 --> 00:06:13.050
you get to take a shot
in the basketball hoop.

144
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:15.560
Now if you do make a shot in
the basketball hoop we give

145
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:16.840
you a $10 gas card.

146
00:06:16.840 --> 00:06:18.310
They get recognized twice,
you get two shots.

147
00:06:18.310 --> 00:06:21.810
You make it both times,
you get $20 in gas cards.

148
00:06:21.810 --> 00:06:25.470
And everybody who gets recognized every
single week, gets an opportunity to go up

149
00:06:25.470 --> 00:06:27.910
to the basketball hop, and
everybody cheers him on.

150
00:06:27.910 --> 00:06:29.970
Everybody gets excited
when Peter would go up and

151
00:06:29.970 --> 00:06:33.140
make it, everybody gets even more
excited because he just won.

152
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:37.970
Again, creating that family unit,
creating that fun activity, creating that

153
00:06:37.970 --> 00:06:42.560
kind of culture inside your company
is what Millennials are looking for.

154
00:06:42.560 --> 00:06:46.780
Aside from that everybody on your team
will enjoy having more fun at work.

155
00:06:46.780 --> 00:06:49.940
It's a fun activity, it's a team building
activity and Peter you couldn't have said

156
00:06:49.940 --> 00:06:53.610
it better, but It's family right
this is what we do with family.

157
00:06:53.610 --> 00:06:56.720
In your house you celebrate birthdays,

158
00:06:56.720 --> 00:07:00.440
right, why not do it with
your family at work right?

159
00:07:00.440 --> 00:07:02.660
I mean, maybe it doesn't need
to be as much as ours, but

160
00:07:02.660 --> 00:07:05.760
you should have some kind of recognition
for your team it's a birthday.

161
00:07:05.760 --> 00:07:08.550
Maybe that doesn't work for
your culture, that's fine.

162
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:11.120
Celebrate a win, get creative,

163
00:07:11.120 --> 00:07:13.650
I mean there's different things
that can happen in every company.

164
00:07:13.650 --> 00:07:16.360
I've heard one company I recently visit,
they do something,

165
00:07:16.360 --> 00:07:18.170
I think it was called like beer 30 or

166
00:07:18.170 --> 00:07:22.710
Fridays around 4:30 in the afternoon
I mean they would have like beer.

167
00:07:22.710 --> 00:07:24.630
>> That sounds like an amazing plan.

168
00:07:24.630 --> 00:07:26.430
>> Yeah, I mean, that's crazy right?

169
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:27.020
Who does that?

170
00:07:27.020 --> 00:07:29.780
I know, HR people cover your ears,
I know how it is.

171
00:07:29.780 --> 00:07:31.950
Trust me.
I deal with HR people all the time.

172
00:07:31.950 --> 00:07:33.270
You don't want to hear
those kind of things.

173
00:07:33.270 --> 00:07:36.060
Just cover your ears, but
that kind of stuff is fun.

174
00:07:36.060 --> 00:07:38.950
That kind of stuff creates an environment
and if it's true to your culture,

175
00:07:38.950 --> 00:07:41.040
if it's true to the way
that your team operates and

176
00:07:41.040 --> 00:07:44.040
your team will naturally
enjoy that then why not?

177
00:07:44.040 --> 00:07:45.310
Let them have fun.

178
00:07:45.310 --> 00:07:46.500
That's what Millennials want, and

179
00:07:46.500 --> 00:07:48.340
I guarantee the rest of your
team will want the same thing.

180
00:07:48.340 --> 00:07:49.660
>> And
I know what you might be thinking of, hey,

181
00:07:49.660 --> 00:07:51.280
you're taking the whole afternoon off?

182
00:07:51.280 --> 00:07:54.280
All the productivity that
that's getting rid of.

183
00:07:54.280 --> 00:07:57.230
But when you've got this family
environment, and you've got people that

184
00:07:57.230 --> 00:08:00.040
honestly care about each other, then
they're gonna work harder for each other.

185
00:08:00.040 --> 00:08:02.390
They're more accountable to each other,
and

186
00:08:02.390 --> 00:08:05.140
that return is gonna come back ten fold.

187
00:08:05.140 --> 00:08:07.190
>> Yep, definitely, every single time.

188
00:08:07.190 --> 00:08:10.270
You can make the argument, well,
we lose so much productivity.

189
00:08:10.270 --> 00:08:13.060
I think my team, honestly, comes back and

190
00:08:13.060 --> 00:08:16.780
they're more productive because
they don't wanna lose that.

191
00:08:16.780 --> 00:08:19.830
Those type of perks,
they don't wanna lose that.

192
00:08:19.830 --> 00:08:22.610
They have a sense of ownership
of what they're responsible for.

193
00:08:22.610 --> 00:08:25.510
They say we really enjoy doing this,
so now I'm gonna work

194
00:08:25.510 --> 00:08:28.890
twice as hard to make up those extra
hours and I'm gonna get my work done.

195
00:08:28.890 --> 00:08:30.020
I don't have a problem with productivity.

196
00:08:30.020 --> 00:08:34.820
I mean my team excels every single time
they knock our goals out of the park

197
00:08:34.820 --> 00:08:36.150
every single time.

198
00:08:36.150 --> 00:08:39.380
And we take more time off, we take
more time to have fun with each other.

199
00:08:39.380 --> 00:08:43.200
And this is an environment that's really,
really awesome.

200
00:08:43.200 --> 00:08:45.880
And I think that's the kind of culture
which we need to strive to create

201
00:08:45.880 --> 00:08:47.530
in our companies today.

202
00:08:47.530 --> 00:08:49.090
If you wanna attract not only Millennials,
but

203
00:08:49.090 --> 00:08:53.530
continue to attract and retain A players
and talented rock stars in our team.

204
00:08:53.530 --> 00:08:54.030
>> Fantastic.

205
00:08:54.030 --> 00:08:58.150
Well, I had a lot of fun in this episode,
but we are out of time for this one.

206
00:08:58.150 --> 00:08:59.730
Any final closing thoughts?

207
00:08:59.730 --> 00:09:01.190
>> Yeah, so last thing I just wanna leave.

208
00:09:01.190 --> 00:09:03.530
I wanna really encourage and
challenge all of our entrepreneurs and

209
00:09:03.530 --> 00:09:06.520
business leaders out there to
really take the opportunity to

210
00:09:07.560 --> 00:09:11.560
challenge yourself on how you can
create fun inside your organization.

211
00:09:11.560 --> 00:09:15.890
So what can you do, what activities can
you engage in that will actually increase

212
00:09:15.890 --> 00:09:19.630
the morale, increase the productivity and
increase the engagement and

213
00:09:19.630 --> 00:09:23.110
retention of your team into
your organization today?

214
00:09:23.110 --> 00:09:23.830
Get creative and

215
00:09:23.830 --> 00:09:28.660
if you have no idea where to start the
best place to start is go ask your team.

216
00:09:28.660 --> 00:09:31.060
Send out a quick email,
don't get all fancy about it.

217
00:09:31.060 --> 00:09:35.680
Say hey, what do you guys think we can
do to incorporate fun in our company?

218
00:09:35.680 --> 00:09:36.570
Very simple.

219
00:09:36.570 --> 00:09:38.220
Let them tell you.

220
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:40.270
That's the key right there, listen, right?

221
00:09:40.270 --> 00:09:41.340
We have two ears, one mouth.

222
00:09:41.340 --> 00:09:44.150
It's important that we listen
twice as much as we speak and

223
00:09:44.150 --> 00:09:45.710
as leaders, we need to learn to listen.

224
00:09:45.710 --> 00:09:49.460
It's not about us, it's about our team and
what can we do to encourage our team and

225
00:09:49.460 --> 00:09:51.830
what do they want that's
gonna motivate them.

226
00:09:51.830 --> 00:09:53.280
>> That's awesome.
Thank you so much Javier for

227
00:09:53.280 --> 00:09:53.940
that information.

228
00:09:53.940 --> 00:09:56.210
A lot of great information
in this episode.

229
00:09:56.210 --> 00:09:56.910
Definitely go back and

230
00:09:56.910 --> 00:09:59.140
watch the other episodes before
this if you haven't seen them yet.

231
00:09:59.140 --> 00:10:02.650
Great information there and a lot more to
come so go ahead and stick around, but for

232
00:10:02.650 --> 00:10:04.470
now signing off I'm Peter VanRysdam.

233
00:10:04.470 --> 00:10:07.170
>> And I'm Javier Montes, your Millennial
expert thank you for tuning in.

234
00:10:07.170 --> 00:10:07.936
>> Bye bye.

235
00:10:07.936 --> 00:10:17.936
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Provide Leadership Not Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.390
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.390 --> 00:00:08.172
Hello and welcome to the show,
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and today,

3
00:00:08.172 --> 00:00:10.597
we're continuing to talk
about millennials and

4
00:00:10.597 --> 00:00:13.740
specifically, what they're looking for
in the workplace.

5
00:00:13.740 --> 00:00:16.470
I know we got a great topic today,
and here to help us with that,

6
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:20.440
we have the author of the new book,
Millennial Workforce Javier.

7
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:21.690
Javier, how you doing today?

8
00:00:21.690 --> 00:00:23.740
>> I'm doing fantastic Peter,
thank you for having me.

9
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:27.560
It's always a pleasure to be here with
you, thank you again for having me and

10
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:31.680
talking about my favorite topic in
the world right now, Millennials.

11
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:34.510
>> I knew it that time, it is just
Millennials, they're your favorite topic.

12
00:00:34.510 --> 00:00:39.740
And today we're talking about how to
lead Millennials in this episode.

13
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:42.550
So what do you mean when you say provide,
what do say,

14
00:00:42.550 --> 00:00:44.400
provide leadership not management.

15
00:00:44.400 --> 00:00:47.530
>> Yeah, Peter, so this a great concept,
and this is what I talk about

16
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:52.030
in our chapter in the book about what
do Millennials want in the workplace.

17
00:00:52.030 --> 00:00:55.890
So what are Millennials exactly looking
for when choosing a company to work for?

18
00:00:55.890 --> 00:00:59.970
And this topic dives into providing
leadership, and not management.

19
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:00.860
Like what's the difference?

20
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:05.475
What is it that we're doing differently
when we lead verses when we manage?

21
00:01:05.475 --> 00:01:07.080
And this is not a new concept,

22
00:01:07.080 --> 00:01:10.220
this is a concept that's been around for
years and years and years.

23
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:14.140
I think I first heard of this concept
from Jack Welsh, right, from GE.

24
00:01:14.140 --> 00:01:17.080
I think he's the first one to kind
of really talk about this concept.

25
00:01:17.080 --> 00:01:18.080
And for many,

26
00:01:18.080 --> 00:01:21.820
many years I think corporate America has
lead with this concept of management.

27
00:01:21.820 --> 00:01:26.300
And it's easy to see just in titles,
right, so we have managers, and

28
00:01:26.300 --> 00:01:31.150
mid level managers, and
just the title itself has led to,

29
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:33.700
lead us to think that
we're currently managing.

30
00:01:33.700 --> 00:01:38.580
Like now coming into what I call the newer
times, the future you see more and

31
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:41.130
more titles coming around like team lead.

32
00:01:41.130 --> 00:01:43.440
Right, program lead, right,

33
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.740
this concept of leading really needs to
be injected into our companies today.

34
00:01:47.740 --> 00:01:48.720
So what's the difference, right?

35
00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:51.930
Let's talk about that, so management,
I think Jack Welsh talked about it.

36
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:56.420
And the way I like to define management
versus leading is managers tell and

37
00:01:56.420 --> 00:01:58.270
leaders show, right.

38
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:00.810
So, a manager tells
somebody to do something,

39
00:02:00.810 --> 00:02:03.670
a leader will show somebody
how to do something, right.

40
00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:07.200
A leader leads by example,
a manager tells people what to do and

41
00:02:07.200 --> 00:02:09.100
not necessarily does it themselves.

42
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:11.710
And I think Millennials are really,
really keen on this.

43
00:02:11.710 --> 00:02:17.330
And they really want to be provided that
leadership, not necessarily be managed,

44
00:02:17.330 --> 00:02:19.910
and this goes down into
micromanaging as well.

45
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:24.320
This goes down into really trying
to get control of your team versus

46
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:27.960
being the leader that your team looks
up to and wants to follow and be like.

47
00:02:27.960 --> 00:02:30.360
And I think that's
the biggest difference there.

48
00:02:30.360 --> 00:02:33.680
>> Yeah and a term I've heard recently too
especially in the IT world where we're

49
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:39.460
talking about agile, work environments
is the leader is a servant leader.

50
00:02:39.460 --> 00:02:43.220
So they're more saying what can I
do to help you do your job better,

51
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:45.580
what obstacles can I
take out of your way so

52
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:47.700
that you can do your job
as efficiently as possible?

53
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:49.960
And I think that's an amazing shift,

54
00:02:49.960 --> 00:02:53.200
to have the leader call themselves
the servant because that's

55
00:02:53.200 --> 00:02:55.830
really what they're doing is
helping you do your job better.

56
00:02:55.830 --> 00:02:59.930
Yeah I think that the best companies
that I've seen the best the most high

57
00:02:59.930 --> 00:03:04.710
productive organisations that I've seen
when I meet with other business leaders.

58
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:07.860
And we interview them and
talk with them I think the biggest

59
00:03:07.860 --> 00:03:12.650
difference that I see is that they hire
people who are good at what they do,

60
00:03:12.650 --> 00:03:15.270
who are really,
really passionate about what they do.

61
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:18.750
And then these leaders kind of tell
them what the expectations are.

62
00:03:18.750 --> 00:03:21.120
So say, here I expect you to produce x,
y, and z.

63
00:03:21.120 --> 00:03:24.730
And then these best leaders
get out of their way,

64
00:03:24.730 --> 00:03:29.140
like literally say go do your thing
because you should know what you're doing,

65
00:03:29.140 --> 00:03:31.398
and you're the rock star,
and that's why I hired you.

66
00:03:31.398 --> 00:03:34.760
And they led them in a way that says,
this is what the end product is,

67
00:03:35.970 --> 00:03:40.190
this is what success looks like,
now go ahead and do it.

68
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:41.900
The managers, what do the managers do?

69
00:03:41.900 --> 00:03:45.570
The managers go in and start saying,
hey what are you gonna do today?

70
00:03:45.570 --> 00:03:47.610
Tell me what you're gonna do
because I think you should do this.

71
00:03:47.610 --> 00:03:49.668
What are you gonna do this week?

72
00:03:49.668 --> 00:03:52.708
No, what I want you to do is,
I want you to do this right.

73
00:03:52.708 --> 00:03:56.931
You start telling them and literally
in essence micromanaging your team,

74
00:03:56.931 --> 00:04:00.830
step by step and really trying to
get control of what they're doing.

75
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:05.462
And their productivity typically tends
starts going down, this is a concept

76
00:04:05.462 --> 00:04:11.220
that's really, I can't imagine how many
years this has been going on, right.

77
00:04:11.220 --> 00:04:15.540
This managing concept, it's kinda
like a punitive type of management.

78
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:19.460
>> Well I think that happens in
a lot of cases where a manager

79
00:04:19.460 --> 00:04:21.250
is worried about their own job security.

80
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:24.260
And maybe hires people that don't want
to be stars because they don't wanna

81
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:25.630
lose their own position.

82
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:26.820
I think the great managers,

83
00:04:26.820 --> 00:04:29.660
the really great ones, are the ones
that are confident enough to go out and

84
00:04:29.660 --> 00:04:31.800
hire people that they know
are smarter than them.

85
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:33.510
People that might be
better at that specific

86
00:04:33.510 --> 00:04:34.890
job that they're asking them to do.

87
00:04:34.890 --> 00:04:38.770
You might be a great leader, but
the person that I need to do this role,

88
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:40.790
they're gonna be the expert at that and
that's great.

89
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:43.360
And it's not hard for me to find
people that are smarter than me.

90
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:46.610
But I think a lot of employees, or
a lot of companies need to go and

91
00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:49.110
take that approach and say,
I trust you to do your job.

92
00:04:49.110 --> 00:04:51.350
And I'm gonna give you
the right direction to do it.

93
00:04:51.350 --> 00:04:55.710
>> Yeah, I think so, and I'll be honest,
as a leader, as an entrepreneur,

94
00:04:55.710 --> 00:05:00.390
it's very difficult to let
go of the reins, right.

95
00:05:00.390 --> 00:05:05.140
To really get out of the weeds, and
kinda let go of or relinquish control.

96
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:08.710
That's a very difficult thing to do,
I struggled with it for many, many years.

97
00:05:08.710 --> 00:05:13.931
As entrepreneurs, I think as type A
personalities it's natural to think that,

98
00:05:13.931 --> 00:05:17.270
well nobody's ever gonna
do it as good as me.

99
00:05:17.270 --> 00:05:18.930
Nobody's ever gonna be as efficient as me,

100
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:20.530
nobody's ever gonna be able
to sell as good as me.

101
00:05:20.530 --> 00:05:23.780
Nobody's ever gonna be able to do x,
y, or z as good as me.

102
00:05:23.780 --> 00:05:27.570
And you know, the truth is while, and

103
00:05:27.570 --> 00:05:29.610
one of my mentors told me this many,
many years ago.

104
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:35.220
The truth is the key is finding
people who cannot be as good as you.

105
00:05:35.220 --> 00:05:39.980
Because you're probably never gonna find
somebody as good as you in your standards.

106
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:45.548
The key is to find somebody who can do
the work at least 70% as good as you.

107
00:05:45.548 --> 00:05:49.750
And free up 100% of your time,
that's the key.

108
00:05:49.750 --> 00:05:53.000
If you can get to that,
that is considered success and

109
00:05:53.000 --> 00:05:55.440
once you get to that then
you'll be able to say, okay,

110
00:05:55.440 --> 00:05:59.100
this person can do it 70% as good as me,
the result gets done.

111
00:05:59.100 --> 00:06:01.905
It's 70% as good and
my time is 100% freed,

112
00:06:01.905 --> 00:06:04.069
then you let go completely of control.

113
00:06:04.069 --> 00:06:05.301
When you do that,

114
00:06:05.301 --> 00:06:10.488
when you do that you will allow your
team to spread their wings and take off.

115
00:06:10.488 --> 00:06:14.709
And I found that nine out of ten times,
when that happens, this person will

116
00:06:14.709 --> 00:06:19.360
outperform anything that you ever did,
and actually be better than you.

117
00:06:19.360 --> 00:06:23.180
The problem is that we tend to
like micromanage and control, and

118
00:06:23.180 --> 00:06:25.920
we teach them to do things
exactly as we do it.

119
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:29.700
And it's not their style or
it's not their forte to do it your way.

120
00:06:29.700 --> 00:06:32.890
They can do it their way,
they're probably experts at it but

121
00:06:32.890 --> 00:06:36.670
since you're holding down their wings,
they can never get past that 70%.

122
00:06:36.670 --> 00:06:41.390
It's only when we step back and
truly allow them to spread their

123
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:45.290
wings that they can actually go out and
be better than you at what they did.

124
00:06:45.290 --> 00:06:46.917
And that seems only hard for
them in the first place.

125
00:06:46.917 --> 00:06:48.760
>> Yeah, and
you used a sports example earlier.

126
00:06:48.760 --> 00:06:50.780
I think this lends itself
really well as well,

127
00:06:50.780 --> 00:06:54.731
if you're on a basketball team you
can't play all the positions at once.

128
00:06:54.731 --> 00:06:57.490
And if you just hog the ball and
say I'm the best, I'm the one that knows

129
00:06:57.490 --> 00:07:01.230
how to do this everyone gets to guard
you and you're not gonna do well.

130
00:07:01.230 --> 00:07:04.688
You look at Micheal Jordan, one of
the greatest basketball players of all

131
00:07:04.688 --> 00:07:07.697
time and he's able to do what he
does because he passes the ball,

132
00:07:07.697 --> 00:07:11.187
he shares with his team, he gets them
opened, and in turn he gets opened.

133
00:07:11.187 --> 00:07:14.735
And it works better when you surround
yourself people that, I mean,

134
00:07:14.735 --> 00:07:17.551
those weren't amazing
players that were around him,

135
00:07:17.551 --> 00:07:21.610
but they were able to do amazing things
because they worked together as a team.

136
00:07:21.610 --> 00:07:26.438
>> Yeah, definitely, and again, going
back, right, we gotta really get past

137
00:07:26.438 --> 00:07:29.961
this, as a society,
get past this concept of managing.

138
00:07:29.961 --> 00:07:34.270
I think this is a dated concept, I think
this is a concept that really should be

139
00:07:34.270 --> 00:07:38.003
phased out of the workplace and
we really need to focus on leading.

140
00:07:38.003 --> 00:07:39.660
How do we lead our team?

141
00:07:39.660 --> 00:07:41.980
How do we improve ourselves as leaders?

142
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:45.410
How do we encourage our
team to be leaders, right?

143
00:07:45.410 --> 00:07:48.500
We need to teach them to be leaders
because not necessarily are they

144
00:07:48.500 --> 00:07:49.250
born leaders.

145
00:07:49.250 --> 00:07:51.440
Maybe they never taught leadership skills,
so

146
00:07:51.440 --> 00:07:55.230
we need to bring that into the forefront
and teach our entire team to be leaders.

147
00:07:55.230 --> 00:07:59.040
Like I mentioned before, everybody in my
company, you do not get promoted until

148
00:07:59.040 --> 00:08:01.720
you teach somebody everything you know and
they can do your job.

149
00:08:01.720 --> 00:08:04.770
It's the only way you get promoted,
that's what a leader does.

150
00:08:04.770 --> 00:08:05.910
A leader leads by examples,

151
00:08:05.910 --> 00:08:09.160
let me show you, let me build you,
let me encourage you.

152
00:08:09.160 --> 00:08:12.609
Those are the kinda things that
really make for great organizations,

153
00:08:12.609 --> 00:08:16.717
great environments, great cultures and
great collaboration amongst your team.

154
00:08:16.717 --> 00:08:19.741
It's important that we
start leading our team,

155
00:08:19.741 --> 00:08:22.700
be the leader that your
team wants to look up to.

156
00:08:22.700 --> 00:08:24.433
Your team wants to follow somebody, right?

157
00:08:24.433 --> 00:08:27.002
They wanna follow your vision,
they wanna follow your dream,

158
00:08:27.002 --> 00:08:28.810
they wanna follow your purpose.

159
00:08:28.810 --> 00:08:31.667
But if we sit there and micromanage and
tell them what to do and

160
00:08:31.667 --> 00:08:34.413
constantly be putting that
kind of management pressure,

161
00:08:34.413 --> 00:08:37.228
you're never gonna allow your
team to spread their wings.

162
00:08:37.228 --> 00:08:39.610
You're never gonna allow
them to be leaders and

163
00:08:39.610 --> 00:08:44.160
you're never gonna be able to be a leader
yourself, so it's kinda counter-intuitive.

164
00:08:44.160 --> 00:08:46.570
We want the freedom, but at the same time,
we don't give any freedom.

165
00:08:46.570 --> 00:08:48.806
>> And that leader needs to remember
they're part of the team and

166
00:08:48.806 --> 00:08:49.803
they need to work that way.

167
00:08:49.803 --> 00:08:54.124
It's not an adversarial attitude, like you
might've seen 50 years ago in a factory

168
00:08:54.124 --> 00:08:57.969
with a supervisor and the people out in
the line, you need to work together and

169
00:08:57.969 --> 00:09:00.710
they're really an important
part of the team.

170
00:09:00.710 --> 00:09:01.294
So, any final thoughts?

171
00:09:01.294 --> 00:09:03.210
I know we're getting close on time here.

172
00:09:03.210 --> 00:09:08.325
>> Yeah, just to close off,
with Millennials, leadership is key.

173
00:09:08.325 --> 00:09:11.465
I think that's the style of management,
if you wanna call it per se,

174
00:09:11.465 --> 00:09:12.925
that they're really looking for.

175
00:09:12.925 --> 00:09:16.875
Again, they're looking up to the
entrepreneurs that are really exceeding

176
00:09:16.875 --> 00:09:18.525
and doing amazing things in the world.

177
00:09:18.525 --> 00:09:21.705
Every single one of those entrepreneurs
are great leaders, and I think that's what

178
00:09:21.705 --> 00:09:25.285
we need to be focusing on is really again
looking back in the mirror and focusing on

179
00:09:25.285 --> 00:09:29.720
our self and saying, am I being that
leader that I want my team to follow?

180
00:09:29.720 --> 00:09:31.480
Or am I being a manager?

181
00:09:31.480 --> 00:09:32.430
What am I being right now?

182
00:09:32.430 --> 00:09:35.060
Because this is the new
style of the world today.

183
00:09:35.060 --> 00:09:38.220
And I think that that's what we need to
push forward, not only will Millennial's

184
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:41.420
really love this concept and they'll
appreciate you more, and follow you more.

185
00:09:41.420 --> 00:09:44.540
But I think every single generation
will also appreciate that as well.

186
00:09:44.540 --> 00:09:46.542
And we need to start incorporating
that in all of our work places.

187
00:09:46.542 --> 00:09:49.430
>> Those are great words to live by,
I think a fantastic point for

188
00:09:49.430 --> 00:09:51.630
us to go ahead, and
wrap up for this episode.

189
00:09:51.630 --> 00:09:54.450
So signing off,
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam.

190
00:09:54.450 --> 00:09:56.935
>> And I'm Javier Montes, your
Millennial expert, thanks for tuning in.

191
00:09:56.935 --> 00:09:57.609
>> See you next time.

192
